Donald is a 33-year-old farmer who lives in the village of St. T. in Alicia, Isabela. He is married to Velita T.. They were blessed with a son, Warren, who is four years old. Donald's wife manages a store in their village. Her job provides them with an alternative source of income. 

Donald is requesting a loan of PHP 25,000 to support his rice farming business, which will lead to a higher income. Donald chose to take out a loan with Kiva through ASKI because it is better than the traders or capitalist in their town. Donald hopes that Kiva lenders will fund his loan so that he can expand his business.

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Eddison

texts.en:
Every harvest season, Eddison is able to generate around PHP 30,000 net income from his one-hectare rice field. Eddison is requesting a loan of PHP 25,000 that he will use to improve his farm.  With the help of the loan, he hopes to harvest a higher yield so he can save and pay for the education of his children. 
                              
Eddison is 38 years old and is married to Chona, who is a domestic helper abroad. Eddison is a good father of two children: Devorah is an 18-year-old college student and Michael Vincent is 16 years old and a senior in high school. His family resides in Barangay St. T. Alicia, Isabela, a rural area where farming is the main source of income of most of the people.

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Emelyn

texts.en:
Emelyn manages an eatery business in the public market of Cauayan City. She is requesting a loan amounting to PHP15,000 for her business to grow. She will be able to encourage more customers by having different menus of food to offer. Through this, Emelyn will surely increase her business profit, which will enable her to meet her family's basic necessities and the education of her children. She is hoping that soon she will be given the business financial support she needs. 
She is now 45 years old and is married to Noel who is working in a bakeshop. They are blessed with five children: Mark Joseph - 19 years old, Norilyn - 18 years old, Maica Angelyn - 16 years old, Lovelyn Joy- 14 years old, and their youngest is Noriel - 5 years old. The family is residing at Barangay San Fermin, Cauayan City. Emelyn is patiently doing her best to maintain her eatery business in order to send all of her children to school to gain a college degree someday.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric is requesting a loan amounting to PHP 16,000 to provide needed capital for his rice-farming business. According to him, having enough capital in farming is necessary in order to generate a high yield in the coming harvest season. He will use the loan to buy fertilizer and seeds for his farm and compensate his hired laborers.  He hopes that through the loan he will be able to put in the needed work to have a strong and plentiful harvest.

Eric is 34 years old and is married to Marife.  They have three children and are harmoniously living at Barangay St.Tomas Alicia, Isabela, a typical village where most people make a living farming. There is a well-irrigated place six kilometers away from their town so there is enough water for all the crops. His wife is a direct seller of personal collection.  With his strong faith in God, Eric firmly shared that “in everything we do, we must put God first”.

Shown with Eric in the picture is a field staff of ASKI.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer and pay his hired laborers

loans.name: Estanley Edgar

texts.en:
Estanley Edgar T. is 48 years old and has three children with his first wife. They are all living and working in Manila.  His second wife is Corazon, a widow with six children.  At the moment, Estanley lives with Corazon’s family and he is supporting the education of his stepchildren through his fish and farming business in their village at St. T. in Alicia, Isabela. He would like to borrow PHP 16,000 for his business. Aside from his fish and farming business, they are also engaged in a catering business that Corazon manages.  
He believes that there is no time in life that is a waste, “The only time we waste is the time we spend thinking that we are not worthy enough to do a task."

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Eulogio

texts.en:
Eulogio is a farmer. He is married to Elsa D. G. and they have two children: Emerson is 15 years old and in the first year of college while Richard is 21 years old and works as a teacher. His wife manages a dry-goods business and sells second-hand clothes. They are living harmoniously in Barangay St. Tomas in Alicia, Isabela, which it is a rural village where most of the residents till rice fields as their major source of income. 

He was encouraged to request a loan of PHP 13,000.00 due to his need of financial support. The amount will enable him to buy his needed farming inputs such as fertilizers, herbicides and insecticiD.. He further said that through hard work, he will become a successful farmer.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa S. is from the village of San Jose, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 31 years old. Marissa is married and has three infant children. To make a living, Marissa owns & operates a "sari-sari" or general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Marissa has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 7,200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marissa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marissa is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marissa from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business and to sustain her family's basic needs. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: San Jose, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Jocelle Sherwin

texts.en:
At the age of 21, Jocelle Sherwin is now very responsible for his family. He is also a hard working person, and he knows how every cent is spent in his business. With his desire to become a successful farmer in the future, he is requesting to borrow a loan of PHP 25,000 to sustain the rice field entrusted to him by his father. Sometimes, with his income in the business, he is able to extend financial assistance to his younger sister who is currently studying. Sherwin believes that being an industrious person, he can become successful like other farmers in his village. He is proud of his choice and is really working to sustain and improve his farm.

Shown in the picture with Jocelle is a field person (the one in a jacket) from ASKI.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Joselito

texts.en:
“Better works makes bigger dreams,” said Joselito Ordońez

Joselito is a farmer and is 44 years old. He is married to Glicilda who is also an entrepreneur and has been operating her store for five years.  They have two children: Sherwin, 20 years old, unfortunately did not finish his college studies and presently manages his rice field. He is already married. Glejel is 14 years old and in the fourth year of high school. They are currently residing in Barangay, St. Tomas Alicia, in the Province of Isabela.  Joselito is requesting a loan of PHP 35,000 to use as financial assistance for his farming. In his farming, he has and will continue to work hard for his family.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Ronaldo

texts.en: Ronaldo D. is 24 years old and is married to Rodaly. They have a two-year-old daughter named Angel. They are residing at Barangay St. Tomas, “where you can find hard working people,” says Ronaldo. He is a simple farmer who is asking the assistance of lenders to finance his rice farming. He is requesting a loan of PHP 16,000. According to Ronaldo, he will utilize his requested loan to purchase fertilizers, pesticides and some other farm inputs he needs. He hopes with the help of this loan that his harvest will be strong and his business will grow over time.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa S. is from the town of Plaridel. She is 43 years old. Elsa is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Elsa owns & operates a business running a food stall. In her food stall she sells a variety of food products to the local community. Elsa has been engaged in her business for over 16 years and earns approximately PHP 5,000 a month for these activities.

In 2007, Elsa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsa has successfully repaid a previous loan of PHP 20,000 from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand product offering. Elsa is requesting a new loan of PHP 20000 which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Elsa from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Darwin

texts.en:
Darwin A. is from the town of Plaridel. He is 31 years old. Darwin is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Darwin owns & operates a fishing business harvesting & selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Darwin has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately PHP 5,000 a month for these activities.

In 2007, Darwin joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Darwin has successfully repaid a previous loan of PHP 4,000 from PMPC. Darwin is requesting a new loan of PHP 6,000, which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Darwin from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets.

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Ly Y., 47, is married with two children and resides in Phnom Penh city. She sells soup and rice to earn approximately US$5 profit every day. Her husband sells ice cream and makes US$6 per day. Their two children also sell ice cream. Ly Y. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to reinvest in her soup and rice shop. She will increase the amount of rice she sells. (Ly was not available so her husband is pictured instead).

loans.use: To reinvest in her soup and rice shop.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mao S. is 36 years old and lives in Phnom Penh city. To earn a living, she has been selling sugar cane juice and beverages in front of the garment factory since 2004. She is able to make US$5 profit per day. Her husband is a construction worker who makes US$3 every day. This couple has two young children who attend school. Mao S. would like to take out a loan to purchase more beverages to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To purchase more beverages to sell.

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Heng S., 40, is married and lives with her five children in Phnom Penh. She is a local teacher and also sells grocery items, making around US$4 each day. Her husband works as a motor-taxi driver. Her husband makes about US$8 each day. However, they must also support an older sister and mother at home. Heng S. is asking for a loan of US$1200 to purchase groceries in bulk so that she can have a special discount from the wholesaler. She is confident that this will be a good business venture and sees it as a tool to increase her income and raise her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase groceries in bulk.

loans.name: El

texts.en: El P., 48, lives in Phnom Penh with his wife and two of his children. He is a professional tailor who makes approximately US$4 per day. His wife also work as a tailor and makes US$3 per day. One of their children is a tailor and one other is a student. El P. is asking for a loan to purchase cloth so that they can make more clothes. (El P. is pictured with his wife and his daughter at home).

loans.use: To purchase cloth.

loans.name: Puth

texts.en: Puth E. is 45 years old and lives with her husband and six of her children in Phnom Penh. She opened a small restaurant selling rice and coffee to earn a living. She is able to make US$10 in revenue every day. Her husband is a mechanic and earns US$4 per day. Two of their children are in school and four are employed in different work. Puth E. would like to take out a loan to purchase a sugar cane juice cart, a machine that can squeeze and produce sugar cane juice. This machine she will give to one of her children to run a business from home.

loans.use: To purchase a machine that can produce sugar cane juice.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia B. is from the village of Militar, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 31 years old. Lydia is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Lydia owns & operates a business venture in the transportation sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating a pedicab transport service. Lydia has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Lydia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lydia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to repair her existing vehicle for better service. Lydia is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to repair her existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lydia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair existing vehicle

loans.name: Naseema Group

texts.en: Naseema is the group leader of Naseema group. There are four members in this group. They want to take a loan of 58800 Afghani and each of them wants to expand her business. Naseema wants to take a loan for her husband who has a general store. Fwarzan wants to take a loan for the business of embroidery. Rawena wants to take a loan for the business of tailoring. Fareda wants to take a loan for her husband who is a taxi driver. So they are very thankful for AFS and Kiva lenders who can support all worlds.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Monina

texts.en:
Monina P. is from the village of Poblacion, Aurora Zamboanga del Sur. She is 49 years old. Monina is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Monina owns & operates a business selling clothes. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling clothes in the local community. Monina has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Monina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Monina is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Monina from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business and to support her family's basic needs. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok B., 36, is a professional weaver who earns approximately US$3 every day. She is married with five children and resides in the Bati district, Takeo province. Her husband is a recycler in the village. He purchases recycling items and resells them to the local factory plant. On average, he makes US$2 per day. Two of their children are in school and three are workers. Sok B. is asking for a loan to purchase a motorbike for her husband to transport recycling items.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Chhim

texts.en: Chhim C., 43, is a local construction worker in the Takeo province. He typically makes US$2 per day. His wife makes and sells silk skirts and cotton scarves and makes US$3 per day. This couple has five children and all of them are in school. Chhim C. would like to take out a loan to purchase more silk skirts and scarves for his wife to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase more silk skirts and scarves.

loans.name: Kuch

texts.en: Kuch C., 51, is a policeman in Takeo province. He has been working as a policeman for ten years and is able to make US$2 per day. His wife grows and sells rice to earn approximately US$1 every day. This couple has three children and all of them are employed in different jobs. Kuch C. would like to take out a loan for his wife to make a new business selling fish in the local market.

loans.use: To start a business selling fish.

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en: Cheng S., 39, is married with one child and resides with her husband in Takeo province. She works in a grocery store and also sells silk skirts and scarves to earn a living. She is able to make US$3 per day. Her husband, El Daravuth, 37, is a local teacher who makes US$2 per day. Cheng S. is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase more silk skirts and scarves. She believes that increasing her inventory and selling the clothes in larger amounts will increase her income and raise her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase more silk skirts and scarves to sell.

loans.name: Vann

texts.en: Vann S. is 30 years old and lives in Takeo province. She is a professional weaver who typically makes US$2.5 profit every day. Her husband is a moto-taxi driver in the local market and is able to make US$7.5 profit per day. This couple has one little child who just attends school. Vann S. is asking for a loan to replace an old and unreliable motorbike for her husband.

loans.use: To replace an old motorbike.

loans.name: Duch

texts.en: Duch S., 55, pictured here with her husband, lives with her husband and four of her children in Takeo province. She and her husband together work making baskets to earn a living and are able to make a combined US$5 every day. Besides making baskets, her husband also purchases and sells cows in the village and he can make an extra US$10 in revenue per day. This couple has four children, three of whom are in school and one is a worker. Duch S. would like to take out a loan to purchase cows for her husband to sell.

loans.use: To purchase cows.

loans.name: Sakina Wali Muhammad Group

texts.en:
Shaheen baji wants a loan to buy material (colored thread, tools) for her carpet weaving business. 
Nawab begum baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 
Hanifan baji wants a loan to buy vehicle engine oil to sell. 
Shakeela baji wants a loan to buy repairing tools for her motor workshop. 

Sakina baji is the wife of W. M. who has lived in Borewala, Pakistan for the last 15 years. Borewala city is famous for its shrines. Her husband works in a motor workshop on a daily wage. He repairs every type of vehicle. He is a trained mechanic. Sakina baji operates a sewing clothes and embroidery business. She takes orders from her neighbors and cloth shops and earns her income after completing the order. She is applying for a loan to buy repairing tools because her husband wants to start his own motor workshop to earn a good income. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy repair tools for motor workshop

loans.name: Sao

texts.en: Sao S., 37, pictured here with her husband, is married with three children and lives in Takeo province. She and her husband work selling rice in the local market and are able to make US$15 in revenue per day. Three of their children are in school. Sao S. would like to take out a loan to purchase rice in bulk so that they can have a special discount and meet their client’s demand, too.

loans.use: To purchase rice in bulk.

loans.name: Khalida Parveen Qasim Ali Group

texts.en:
Nabeela baji wants a loan to buy clothes to sell. 
Muniran baji and Arshad baji each want a loan to buy auto-rickshaws (local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 
Shamim baji wants a loan to buy vehicle oil to sell. 

Khalida parveen baji is a very hardworking lady and a group leader of these above-mentioned ladies. She is a very responsible and good-natured lady. All of her members respect her a lot. She runs her decorative embroidery business. She takes orders from the cloth shops and charges them according to the work. Her husband has a juice corner in the community where he sells different fruit juices and earns an income. People come to him from different communities for juice. Khalida baji is applying for a loan to buy another juicer machine for her husband’s juice corner. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy another juicer machine

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Bun P., 48, pictured here with her husband, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province. To earn a living, she has been selling gas from her home and is able to make about US$12 in revenue per day. Her husband is a mechanic and typically makes US$5 every day. This couple has six children, three of whom are in school and three who work in private companies. Bun P. would like to request a loan from Kiva via CREDIT to purchase a motorbike for her family’s transportation. This will reduce their transportation costs and allow the family to save much more than before.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Kaniz Fatima Muhammad Alam Group

texts.en:
Shamim akhtar baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits & vegetables to sell. 
Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. 

Kaniz Fatima baji is the group leader of the above-mentioned ladies. They all belong to a city named Borewala, Pakistan. Borewala city is famous for its shrines. Kaniz baji is married to M. A. who runs a grocery shop in the community. He has three years of experience in this business. Kaniz baji is a very hardworking lady. She runs a sewing clothes business to pay off the utilities and to share the financial burden with her husband. She is applying for a loan to buy groceries for her husband’s grocery shop. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Rubi Muhammad Shahzad Group

texts.en:
Irshad baji wants a loan to buy electric supplies (wires, switches and switchboards) for her electric supplies selling business. 
Kosar baji wants a loan to buy milk to sell.

Rubi baji is the group leader for these above-mentioned ladies. They all are very hardworking ladies. She runs her sewing clothes business to pay off the utilities of her house. Rubi baji is married to M. S. who is an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) driver. He does not own his rickshaw. That’s why he earns only half of the fare. Rubi baji has saved some money from her sewing clothes business. She is lacking Pak rupees 10,000+/- so she is applying for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) for her husband so that he can get the whole fare.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Zareena Maqbool Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Salma baji wants a loan to buy decorative pieces to sell. 
Shamim akhtar baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.
Shazia baji wants a loan to buy sanitary supplies (pipes and taps) to sell. 
Rukhsana baji wants a loan to buy clothes to sell.

Zareena baji is the leader of above-mentioned ladies. They all belong to a city named Borewala, Pakistan. Borewala city is famous for its shrines. They all are very hardworking ladies. They handle their own businesses to manage the financial expenses of their houses. Zareena baji operates a sewing clothes business to earn income, so that she able to save money for her rainy days. Her husband is an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) driver. He drives a rented rickshaw. He earns half of the fare and pays the remaining half to the owner. She is applying for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) so that her husband is able to earn the whole fare. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Faridah

texts.en: N. Faridah is a businesswoman, 34-years old, and the mother of three children. She operates a bar and she has been operating the bar for over five years. She is requesting a loan to purchase bar items such as beers, wines, spirits, sodas, etc to meet her customer demands. Having used her capital income to purchase land and construct rental houses, the loan will add capital and expand her business. Her future dream is to educate her children and purchase more plots of land to build more rental houses.

loans.use: To purchase bar items such as beers, wines, spirits, sodas, etc.

loans.name: Abida Muhammad Ramzan Group

texts.en:
Najma baji wants a loan to buy decorative pieces to sell. 
Shaheen baji wants a loan to change the body of her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 
Abida baji is the wife of M. R. who has lived in Borewala, Pakistan for the last 15 years. Borewala city is famous for its shrines. Her husband is a motor mechanic and repairs vehicles. He has been doing this work for the last five years. Abida baji operates a sewing clothes business. She sews clothes by taking orders from her neighbors. She charges $2 for stitching. Abida baji saves her income in a committee and plans to renovate her house with a committee amount. She is applying for a loan to buy repairing tools for her husband because he wants to start his own motor workshop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy repairing tools for motor workshop

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en: M. Sylvia is a businesswoman. She is 36-years old and single. She deals in stationery items and she also renders computer services and photocopying. She has been in her business for over 10 years. She is using the loan to purchase stationery items such as reams of paper, charts, pens and pencils, ink, manila papers etc. Her future dream is to build rental houses.

loans.use: To purchase stationery items such as ream of papers, charts, pens and pencils, ink, manila papers etc.

loans.name: Parveen Muhammad Younas Group

texts.en:
Parveen baji has been a citizen of a city named Borewala, Pakistan, for the past 15 years. Borewala is famous for its shrines. Her husband is a delivery man by profession and delivers different items (fruits and vegetables) on his donkey cart. Parveen baji operates a sewing clothes business to pay off the utilities. She is applying a loan to buy a new donkey cart because the old cart has become rough and rotted, affecting her husband's work. She is joined by three other group members.

Khalida baji wants a loan to buy repairing tools for her motor workshop. Razia baji and Majeedan baji each want a loan to buy timber to sell. Kiran baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 

This is a group loan and the loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a new donkey cart

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Ly C. is 47 years old and resides in the Saang district, Cambodia. She is married with seven children. To earn a living, she works in a grocery store and also works with her husband as a construction worker. They make jars, tables and chairs (from cement) and earn ~US$15 every day. While two of her children help them in construction work, her five other children attend school. Ly C. is asking a loan to purchase sand, cement and other construction materials to make more jars, tables and chairs.

loans.use: To purchase sand and cement to build tables and chairs

loans.name: Hanifan Abdul Rasheed Group

texts.en:
Hanifan baji is married to A. R. who runs a construction supplies business. He earns income by taking orders from building contractors. Hanifan baji operates a sewing clothes business to pay off the utilities. Her husband’s business is out of stock; hence Hanifan baji is applying for a loan to buy construction supplies to complete the orders. She is the group leader of two other women.

Shamim baji wants a loan to buy bed sheets to sell. Sajida Mubarak baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

This is a group loan and the loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies to complete the orders

loans.name: Phon

texts.en: Phon P., 29, is married and has a young child living at home in the Saang district, Kandal Province. Working in a grocery store, she typically makes US$8 each day, while her husband, Vong Suth, who buys and sells rice, typically makes about US$12 each day. Phon P. would like a loan of US$1000 to purchase grocery items and rice.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items and rice.

loans.name: Sulaiman

texts.en: Mr. Sulaiman T., a 36-year-old proud father of five children, all in school, is a Kampala businessman dealing in Irish potatoes and sweet potatoes. In business for over 17 years, he brings in truckloads of potatoes from the villages and supplies them to the various marketplaces around town.  Since the demand is high, Sulaiman is now requesting a loan to purchase larger quantities of Irish potatoes and sweet potatoes. His future plans include educating his children and building rental houses to generate more income.

loans.use: To purchase Irish potatoes and sweet potatoes in large quantities.

loans.name: Shakeela Muhammad Akram Group

texts.en:
Naseem akhtar baji wants a loan to buy another juicer machine for her juice corner.

Shabana nasreen baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics for her cosmetics-selling business.

Sharifan baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading.

Salma baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 

Shakeela baji, wife of M. A., has lived in Borewala, Pakistan, for the past fifteen years. Borewala is famous for its shrines. Her husband runs a timber selling business and has been in this business for the past five years.

Shakeela baji is a very hardworking lady. She runs a clothes-sewing business. She takes order from her neighbors and charges them by $2 per stitching. She does this work to pay off the utilities. She is applying for a loan to buy timber to expand her husband’s timber-selling business.

loans.use: To buy timber for her husband's business

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Heng P., a 46-year-old married mother of one child, resides in Kandal Province where she sells porridge and vegetables from her home. She typically makes $15 in revenue per day while her husband, who sells small freshwater shells in the local market, earns about $10 per day. Heng is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase tables and chairs for her porridge shop as well as more vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To purchase tables, chairs, and more vegetables.

loans.name: Angella

texts.en: M. Angella is 48 years old and the mother of four children. She deals in a flower business, supplying flowers to various festivals and functions like wedding parties and other outside catering festivals, offices, hotels, etc. She is using the loan to purchase and maintain flowers for sale. Her future dream is to build a rental house.

loans.use: To purchase and maintain flowers for sale

loans.name: Wakeelan Abdul Wahid Group

texts.en:
Jamila baji wants a loan to buy warm clothes (sweaters) for making woolen balls to sell.

Irshad baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits to sell.

Zobia baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business.

Salma baji wants a loan to buy utensils to sell.

Wakeelan baji is the group leader of these above mentioned ladies. They all belong to Borewala, Pakistan, a city famous for its shrines. They are all very hardworking ladies.

Wakeelan baji prepares embroidered dresses to order. She does this work to share the financial burden of her husband. Her husband runs a timber-selling business. He has 3 years of experience in this business. She is applying for a loan to buy timber to expand his timber-selling business.

Note: Jamila baji is showing her woolen balls which she gets from the old warm sweaters.

loans.use: To buy timber for her husband's business

loans.name: Shabana Begum Raheem Baig Group

texts.en:
Razia baji wants a loan to buy timber to sell.

Shakeela baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

Shabana begum baji is the group leader of these above mentioned ladies. She has been a citizen of Borewala, Pakistan, for the past eight years. Borewala city is famous for its shrines.

Shabana baji runs a clothes-sewing business because she wants to spend an independent life. Her business gives her confidence to fight with circumstances. Her husband is an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) driver. He has been driving this vehicle for the past three years. She is applying for a loan to change the body of her husband’s auto-rickshaw.

loans.use: To change the body of her husband's auto-rickshaw

loans.name: Magret

texts.en: M. Magret is a 38-year-old businesswoman. She is the mother of five children, three of whom are going to school. She has been in the clothes business for over 6 years. She deals in baby clothes, and her shop is located in Kampala town. She will use this loan to purchase baby clothes to sell. Her dream is to buy a plot of land and work hand-in-hand with her husband to educate their children.

loans.use: To purchase baby clothes to sell

loans.name: Razia Muhammad Iqbal Group

texts.en:
Shagufta baji wants a loan to buy plastic beans to sell.
Shamim akhtar baji wants a loan to buy timbers to sell.
Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).
Asia baji wants a loan to buy an iron for making iron rods to sell.
Khursheed baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits to sell.

Razia baji is a wife of M. I.. She has lived in Borewala, Pakistan for the past 7 years. Borewala is a city famous for its shrines. She is the group leader of the ladies listed above. Razia baji is a very hardworking and mature lady. She knows that economic conditions are not so good nowadays, and it’s difficult to rely on a single person’s income. She prepares embroidered dresses in order to ease her husband's tension from being solely responsible for their finances. She is applying for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) for her husband because he currently drives a rented rickshaw.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Winnie

texts.en: M. Winnie is 45 years old and the mother of two children. She is in the bar business on the beach side of Lake Victoria, serving drinks to the people who go out to the beach for recreation. She has been in her business for 4 years.  She will use this loan to purchase various kinds of drinks to meet her customers' demands. Her future plan is to renovate the rental houses for more tenants.

loans.use: To purchase various kinds of drinks

loans.name: Ramzana Mubeen Aslam Group

texts.en:
Sakina baji wants a loan to buy goats to resell.

Khalida parveen baji and Ramzana baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shops.

Kosar parveen baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading.

Ramzana baji is the group leader of these above mentioned ladies and has been a citizen of Borewala, Pakistan, for the past fourteen years. Borewala city is famous for its shrines.

Ramzana baji runs a clothes-sewing business to share the financial burden of her husband. Her husband’s name is M. A. and he runs a timber-selling business. Mostly people come to him to buy timber. She is applying for a loan to buy timber to expand her husband’s timber-selling business.

loans.use: To buy timber for her husband's business

loans.name: Kotognontala 2 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Kotognontala 2 est constitué de femmes du hameau Adamabougou de la ville de Koutiala (troisième région du Mali) qui vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs maris, coépouses, beaux parents, belles sœurs, beaux frères et enfants. Elles ont en moyenne 40 ans et  6 enfants.
Elles cultivent principalement  l’arachide et le mil. 
C’est pour satisfaire  leurs besoins en semences, intrants et petits matériels pour la culture de l’arachide et du mil, sur plus d’une dizaine d’hectares qu’elles  ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a quatre ans (quatre prêts de campagne). Tous les prêts  précédents ont été correctement payés.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter des sacs de semences d’arachide, de mil, d’engrais  et des petits matériels agricoles  au grand marché de Koutiala. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur  avant d’être vendues. Elles vendent leurs productions  dans tous les marchés qui sont aux environs de Koutiala et au grand marché de la ville de Koutiala, en détail, en gros, au comptant surtout à des revendeurs et à quelques consommateurs.
Les femmes du groupe Kotognontala 2 comptent réaliser un bénéfice de 50 000 FCFA chacune après les récoltes.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utiliseront une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The group Kotognontala 2 is composed of women from the hamlet of Adamabougou of Koutiala City (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in large traditional extended families with their husbands, co-wives, parents-in-law, sisters-in-law, brothers-in-law, and children. The group members average 40 years of age and six children each. They grow mainly peanuts and millet. To satisfy their need for seeds, fertilizer, supplies, and equipment for growing peanuts and millet on over a dozen hectares, they decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso four years ago (four farming loans). All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. The current loan will be used to buy sacks of peanut seeds, millet, manure, and farming supplies at the grand marketplace of Koutiala. Following the off-season, the crops are stored for a time, so that they gain in value, and then they are sold. The group members sell their crops, retail and wholesale, particularly in cash to retailers and to a few consumers. The group members each intend to realize a profit of 50,000 francs CFA after the harvests. In addition to repaying the loans, they will use a portion of the revenues to cope with common family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, seeds, and minor farming supplies

loans.name: Sugran Muhammad Arshad Group

texts.en:
My name is Sugran and I have been a citizen of Borewala, Pakistan, for the past ten years. Borewala city is famous for its shrines.

I run a business selling clothes. I know that my husband’s income is insufficient to meet the financial expenses which allows me to run a business to produce more income. I save my income and used it as per need. My husband’s name is M. A. and he runs a fertilizer-selling business. I’m applying for a loan to buy fertilizer to expand my husband’s business.

I’m the group leader of four other women from my locality:

Shaheen kosar baji wants a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides to sell.

Kosar baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

Razia parveen baji wants a loan to buy fertilizer to sell.

Sakina baji wants a loan to buy beams for her shuttering business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her husband's business

loans.name: Mohammad Taher

texts.en: Mohammad Taher is the son of G. A.. He lives in the 6th district of Kabul in Afghanistan. He is fifty years old and married with six children. He is a hard working man who likes having a successful business. He has a shop in which he sells oil, flour and different kinds of cereal. He would like to expand his business and increase his monthly income, so he wants to take out a loan. He says that this kind of program is very helpful for the progress of poor people in Afghanistan.

loans.use: Expanding his business

loans.name: Farzana Kosar Nisar Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Farzana kosar baji, wife of N. A., has been a citizen of Borewala, Pakistan, for the past ten years. Borewala city is famous for its shrines.

Farzana baji runs a clothes-sewing business to earn income. She saves her income and uses it when needed. Her husband runs a fertilizer-selling business. He sells fertilizer to the gardeners. She is applying for a loan to expand her husband’s fertilizer-selling business.

She is the group leader of two other women from her locality:

Shamim akhtar baji wants a loan to buy goats to sell.

Suraiya baji wants a loan to buy fertilizer to sell.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her husband's business

loans.name: Kotognontala 3 Group

texts.fr:
Kotognontala 3 est un regroupement de femmes du hameau Adamabougou de la ville de Koutiala (troisième région du Mali) qui se connaissent bien. Elles vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec en moyenne 38 ans et  6 enfants.
Elles cultivent principalement  l’arachide et le mil  sur plus de six  hectares.
Pour la satisfaction de leurs besoins en semences, intrants et petits matériels agricoles, elles ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a quatre  ans (quatre prêts de campagne). Tous les prêts antérieurs ont été remboursés sans difficulté.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, des sacs de semences d’arachide, de mil, d’engrais et des petits matériels indispensables à  la culture. 
Elles se procurent  en semences, intrants et autres au marché de la ville de  Koutiala auprès des grossistes. 
Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues. Elles vendent les céréales  dans tous les marchés qui sont aux environs de Koutiala et au grand marché surtout aux revendeurs venant des grandes villes. 
Après  la vente de la récolte, les membres du groupe Kotognontala 3 comptent réaliser un bénéfice de 40 000FCFA chacune qui servira pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et le reste utilisé pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Kotognontala 3 is a group of women of the hamlet of Adamabougou of Koutiala City (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know each other well. They live in large traditional extended families and average 40 years of age and at least 6 children each. They grow mainly peanuts and millet on over six hectares. To satisfy their need for seeds, fertilizers, and small farming equipment, the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program four years ago (four farming loans). All the previous loans have been repaid without difficulty. The current loan will be used to buy sacks of seeds for planting peanuts and millet, some manure, and small tools and supplies that are indispensable for farming. These goods are gotten from the Koutiala City market from wholesalers. After the off-season, the crops are stored for a time, so that they gain in value. And then they are sold at the markets in the Koutiala area and at the grand marketplace, especially to retailers from large cities. After the crops are sold, the group members each intend to realize a profit of 40,000 francs CFA that will be used to make loan interest payments, and the rest will be used to cope with common family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, seeds, and equipment and supplies

loans.name: Hamidan Pervaiz Akhtar Group

texts.en:
Hamidan baji is a very hardworking lady. She handles two businesses: one is bangle-selling and the second is sewing clothes. Her customers are from her locality. They come to her both for buying bangles and for sewing clothes. Her family is very happy with her supportive behavior. Her husband’s name is P. A. and he runs a grocery shop in the community. Hamidan baji is applying for a loan to buy groceries to expand her husband’s grocery shop. 

She is the group leader of three other women from her locality:

Rashida parveen baji wants a loan to buy a welding machine.

Shamila parveen baji wants a loan to buy iron for making iron rods to sell.

Abida baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

loans.use: To buy groceries for her husband's grocery shop

loans.name: Mohammad Asef

texts.en: The man who is pictured is M. Asef, the son of M. N.. He lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is forty-five years old and married with four children, two sons and two daughters. In his shop where he sells fuel, he is very busy every day all week except Friday. He would like to make some changes to his business and to purchase what he needs to improve it.  He has requested a loan and would like to say that this loan process supports entrepreneurs very effectively.

loans.use: To buy needed materials for improving his business

loans.name: Parveen Muhammad Aslam Group

texts.en:
Parveen baji, wife of M. A., has lived in Borewala, Pakistan, for the past fourteen years. Borewala city is famous for its shrines.

Parveen baji handles her bangle-selling and clothes-sewing businesses and manages those businesses very efficiently. She is a very hardworking lady. Mostly her customers are from her locality. She saves her income and uses it when needed. Her husband runs a construction supplies business. He fulfills the orders of the building contractors and earns income. She is applying for a loan to buy construction supplies (sand, cement) to expand her husband’s business.

She is the group leader of three other women from her locality:

Jamila baji wants a loan to buy flour to sell.

Naseem akhtar baji and Kalsoom baji each want a loan to buy fertilizer to sell.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies for her husband's business

loans.name: Niagnéguéton 1 Group

texts.fr:
Niagnéguéton 1 est un regroupement de femmes du  hameau Sinsina Sesso de la ville de Koutiala (troisième région administrative du Mali) qui se connaissent bien. Elles vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles avec en moyenne  40 ans et au moins  6 enfants.
Elles cultivent principalement de l’arachide et  du haricot.
 Pour satisfaire leurs besoins en semences, intrants et petits matériels agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a quatre ans. Tous les prêts précédents ont été remboursés correctement.  
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, des petits  matériels agricoles, une quantité suffisante d’intrants, de semences d’arachide et de haricot.
Elles se procurent en ces différents articles au marché de Koutiala et vendent leurs productions (après qu’elles aient eues de la valeur) au grand marché de Koutiala et dans tous les marchés environnants de Koutiala, aux revendeurs et  aux consommateurs. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice de 80 000 FCFA chacune après la vente des récoltes.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Niagnéguéton 1 is a group of women of the hamlet of Sinsina Sesso of Koutiala City (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know one another well. They live in large traditional families and average 40 years of age and at least 6 children each. They grow mainly peanuts and beans. To satisfy their need for seeds, fertilizers, and small farming equipment, the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program four years ago. All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. The current loan will be used to buy farming equipment, a sufficient quantity of fertilizers and the like, and seeds for growing peanuts and beans. Supplies of these different items are gotten at the Koutiala marketplace. Their crops are sold at the grand marketplace of Koutiala (after the crops gain in value). The customers include retailers and consumers. The group members each hope to realize a profit of 80,000 francs CFA after selling the crops. In addition to repaying the loan, a portion of the revenues will be used to cope with common family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, seeds, and small farming supplies

loans.name: Sakina Muhammad Bashir Group

texts.en:
Sakina baji is a widow and has resided in Borewala, Pakistan, for the past fifteen years. Her husband died of a heart attack and left her in a condition where she had no financial resources. She started a clothes-sewing business to earn income. With the profit she was able to start another business and that was selling bangles. She gathers a good number of customers from her variety of bangles. She is very happy with her success and is applying for a loan to buy bangles to expand her bangle-selling business. 

She is the group leader of five other women from her locality:

Hamidan baji, Naseem baji and Jamila baji each want a loan to buy fertilizer to sell.

Sajida parveen baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

Nagina kosar baji wants a loan to buy plastic beans for her business making plastic bags.

loans.use: To buy bangles to expand her business

loans.name: Niagnéguéton 2. Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Niagnéguéton 2 est composé de femmes du hameau Sinsina Sesso de la ville de Koutiala (troisième région du Mali) qui  vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 38 ans et sont mères d’au moins 6 enfants.
Elles cultivent principalement de l’arachide et du mil.
Afin de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a quatre  ans (4 prêts de campagnes).Tous les prêts précédents ont été remboursés sans difficulté. 
 Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, des petits  matériels agricoles et une importante quantité de semences  d’arachide et de mil.
Elles se procurent  en ces semences et petits matériels agricoles au grand  marché de Koutiala.
Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant de les vendre  dans tous les marchés qui sont aux environs de Koutiala et au grand marché essentiellement aux revendeurs. 
Les femmes du groupe Niagnéguéton 2 comptent réaliser un bénéfice de 80 000 FCFA chacune après la vente des récoltes.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Niagnéguéton 2 group is composed of women from the hamlet called Sinsina Sesso of the town of Koutiala (third region of Mali) who live in big traditional families. They have an average age of 38 and each is the mother of at least 6 children. They principally cultivate peanuts and millet.

So as to make their agricultural businesses profitable, the members of the group decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso 4 years ago (4 rural loans). All the preceding loans have been reimbursed without difficulty. The present loan will be used to buy minor agricultural material and a large quantity of seeds of peanut and millet. They get their seeds and materials from the big open-air market of Koutiala.

After the rainy season, the harvest is stocked for some time so that it gains in value before being sold in the markets that surround Koutiala and at the big open-air market, essentially to middlemen.

Each of the women of the Niagnéguéton 2 group expects to make a profit of 80,000 F CFA after the sale of their harvest. Besides reimbursing the loan, they will use part of the income to cover current family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of seeds and minor agricultural materials

loans.name: Zahida

texts.en:
Zahida Bahić was born in 1962 and comes from suburb of the town of Gradačac. She has a husband who is employed in construction work as a seasonal worker.

Zahida has been our client for a long time; she has three successfully repaid loans and is now requesting the fourth one. Zahida is one of those women who wants to make progress every moment. She worked at a market earlier, selling clothes, and she invested her two loans in that. After some time she decided not to work at the market anymore, and she requested her third loan to purchase sheep which she still has.

Now, a business raising poultry seems attractive to Zahida and she has requested a loan from WWI in the amount of 500 KM to purchase poultry and food for them, intending to sell them when they are mature. Zahida hopes to earn and put some money to the side to have it for times when her husband is unemployed.

loans.use: To buy poultry to raise and sell

loans.name: Azimullah

texts.en: This is Azimullah, the son of E.. He lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married with six children, and all of his family members benefit through the income his business generates. He has a general store and in order to expand it he needs a loan. He is glad that all entrepreneurs can improve their businesses and raise their standard of living through these effective programs.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Niagnéguéton 3 Group

texts.fr:
Niagnéguéton 3 est un regroupement de femmes du   hameau Sinsina Sesso de la ville de Koutiala (troisième région du Mali) qui vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles avec  en moyenne 38 ans et au moins  6 enfants.
 Pour satisfaire leurs besoins en semences, intrants et frais de main d’œuvre agricole pour la culture de l’arachide et du mil, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a quatre  ans (4 prêts de campagnes) et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter une quantité suffisante de semences d’arachide, de mil, d’intrants et pour s’acquitter des frais de main d’œuvres agricoles. La main d’œuvre utilisée est essentiellement locale. 
 Elles se procurent en intrants et semences au marché de Koutiala. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues. Elles vendent les céréales  dans tous les marchés qui sont aux environs de Koutiala et au grand marché. 
Les femmes du groupe Niagnéguéton 3 comptent réaliser un bénéfice de 80 000 FCFA chacune après la vente des récoltes.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Niagnéguéton 3 is comprised of women of the Sinsina Sesso hamlet of the town of Koutiala (third region of Mali) who live in big traditional families and have an average age of 38 and at least 6 children, on average.

To satisfy their needs in terms of seed, entrants, and wages for agricultural workers for cultivating peanuts and millet, the members of the group decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso, four years ago (four rural loans). All the preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed.

The present loan will be used to buy a sufficient quantity of peanut and millet seeds, entrants, and to pay the cost of agricultural workers. The workers are essentially local. The women buy entrants and seeds at the market in Koutiala. After the rainy season, the harvests are stocked for a time so that they gain in value before being sold. They sell cereals in all the markets around Koutiala and in the big open-air market.

Each of the women of the Niagnéguéton 3 group expects to make a profit of 80,000 F CFA after the sale of the harvest. Besides reimbursing the loan, they will use a part of the income to cover current family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of entrants, seeds, and paying agricultural laborers

loans.name: Niagnéguéton 4 Group

texts.fr:
Niagnéguéton 4 est un regroupement de femmes du   hameau Sinsina Sesso de la ville de Koutiala (troisième région du Mali) qui   vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies. Elles ont en moyenne 28 ans et sont mères d’au moins 4 enfants.
Elles cultivent principalement de l’arachide et du mil.
Pour satisfaire leur besoin en semences, intrants et petits matériels agricoles pour la culture de l’arachide et du mil, elles ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a quatre  ans (4 prêts de campagnes). Tous le précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, des petits matériels agricoles, une quantité suffisante de semences d’arachide, de mil et d’intrants. 
Elles se procurent  en ces différents articles au marché de Koutiala. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues. Elles vendent les céréales  dans tous les marchés qui sont aux environs de Koutiala et au grand marché. 
Après la vente des récoltes, les femmes du groupe Niagnéguéton 4 comptent réaliser un bénéfice de 80 000 FCFA chacune qui sera utilisé pour faire face aux dépenses familiales et pour le remboursement du prêt.
texts.en:
Niagnéguéton 4 is comprised of women of the Sinsina Sesso hamlet of the town of Koutiala (third region of Mali) who live in big, extended traditional families. They have have an average age of 28 and are the mothers of at least 4 children each. They grow mainly peanuts and millet.

To satisfy their needs in terms of seed, entrants, and minor agricultural material for cultivating peanuts and millet, the members of the group decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso, four years ago (four rural loans). All the preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed.

The present loan will be used to buy minor agricultural material, a sufficient quantity of peanut and millet seeds, and entrants. The women buy these various articles at the market in Koutiala. After the rainy season, the harvests are stocked for a time so that they gain in value before being sold. They sell cereals in all the markets around Koutiala and in the big open-air market.

After the sale of the harvests, each of the women of the Niagnéguéton 4 group expects to make a profit of 80,000 F CFA which will be used to cover current family expenses and reimburse the loan.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of entrants, seeds, and minor agricultural materials

loans.name: Nermina

texts.en:
Nermina Deliomerović is 28 years old and comes from Gradačac. She is employed in a boutique and besides that, she resells clothes and shoes at the market and on order. She has been our client for a long time; this will be her third loan through WWI.

Nermina used the first loan to purchase poultry for resale; the second one was invested in clothing inventory. She is a young girl who wants to earn for her later life and provide a good life standard for herself. Nermina requested 500 KM to by clothes and shoes to resell.

loans.use: To buy clothes and shoes to resell

loans.name: Dost Mohammad

texts.en: Dost M. is the son of M. K. and is a resident of Kabul, Afghanistan, in district 9. He is married with four children and owns a shop in which he sells clothes, like dresses and pants. He wants a loan in order to expand his business by purchasing a variety of clothes which are in demand in the market and which can be sold at a high price. He is glad that such good loan processes exist in Afghanistan for the support of people.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Niagnéguéton 5 Group

texts.fr:
Niagnégueton 5 est un regroupement de femmes mariées du hameau Sinsina Sesso de la ville de Koutiala région  de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs enfants, maris, beaux parents, belles sœurs  etc. Elles ont en moyenne 33 ans et au moins 4 enfants.
Elles excellent principalement  dans la culture de l’arachide et du mil.
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe Niagnégueton 5 ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant quatre ans. Après avoir correctement remboursés  les trois  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur quatrième prêt de campagne.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter exclusivement  au grand marché de Koutiala ville, une quantité suffisante de semences d’arachide, de mil, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture. 
Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Koutiala et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes et aux consommateurs.
Les membres du groupe Niagnégueton 5 comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 80 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  le remboursement du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Niagnéguéton 5 is comprised of married women of the Sinsina Sesso hamlet of the town of Koutiala, region of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They live in big, extended traditional families with their children, husbands, parents-in-law, sisters-in-law, etc. They have an average age of 33 and are the mothers of at least 4 children each. They principally excel in growing peanuts and millet.

In order to make their agricultural businesses profitable, the members of the group Niagnégueton 5 decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso, four years ago. After having correctly reimbursed the three preceding loans, they are now on their fourth rural loan.

The present loan will be used to buy, exclusively in the big open-air market of the town of Koutiala, a sufficient quantity of peanut and millet seeds, minor agricultural materials, and entrants for the crops. After the rainy season, the harvests are stocked for a time so that they gain in value before being sold in the big market of Koutiala and the surrounding markets, retail (often wholesale) for cash, to a clientele mostly coming from the big cities but also to consumers.

After the sale of the harvests, each of the women of the Niagnéguéton 5 group expects to make a profit of 80,000 F CFA which will be used to cover current family expenses and reimburse the loan.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of entrants, seeds, and minor agricultural materials

loans.name: Ghassan

texts.en: Ghassan is a 36-year-old married man with two children, living in Haret Horeik, Mount Lebanon. He has been a juice vendor since 2003, and he services the neighboring areas. Today, Ghassan is requesting to borrow US$ 800 to increase his inventory.

loans.use: increase his inventory

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 50-year-old married man with three children, living in Sfair, Mount Lebanon. He has owned his own mini-market since 1998, with a 15-year experience in the field. Today, Mohamad is requesting to borrow US$ 800 to increase his stock of merchandise.

loans.use: increase his merchandise

loans.name: Niagnéguéton 6 Group

texts.fr:
Niagnéguéton 6 est un regroupement de femmes mariées du hameau Sinsina Sesso de la ville de Koutiala région  de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs enfants, maris, beaux parents, belles sœurs  etc. Elles ont en moyenne 33 ans et au moins 4 enfants.
Elles excellent principalement  dans la culture de l’arachide et du mil.
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe Niagnéguéton 6 ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant quatre ans. Après avoir correctement remboursés  les trois  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur quatrième prêt de campagne.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, des petits matériels agricoles, une quantité suffisante de semences d’arachide, de mil  et d’intrants, au grand marché de Koutiala. 
Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certains  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Koutiala et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail ou en gros, au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe Niagnéguéton 6 comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 80 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  le remboursement du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Niagnéguéton 6 is a group of married women from the Sinsina Sesso hamlet of the town of Koutiala, Sikasso region, (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in big extended traditional families with their children, husbands, parents- and sisters-in-law, etc. They have an average age of 33 and at least 4 children each. They excel principally in the cultivation of peanuts and millet.

In the intention of making their agricultural businesses profitable, the members of the Niagnéguéton 6 group decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso 4 years ago. After having correctly reimbursed the three preceding loans, they are now on their fourth rural loan.

The present loan will be used to buy minor agricultural material, a sufficient quantity of peanut and millet seeds, and entrants, in the big open-air market of Koutiala. After the rainy season, the harvests are stocked for a certain time so that they gain in value before being sold at the big market of Koutiala and in the surrounding markets, retail or wholesale and for cash, to a clientele mostly coming from the big cities.

The members of the Niagnéguéton 6 group each expect to make, after their agricultural produce has been sold, a profit of 80,000 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the loan and cover current family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of entrants, seeds, and minor agricultural materials

loans.name: Sami

texts.en: Sami is a 34-year-old man living in Furn El Chebbak, Mount Lebanon. He has been working in pipe repair for the past nine years. Today, Sami is requesting to borrow US$ 1,200 to purchase tools and goods to increase his sales.

loans.use: purchase tools, etc.

loans.name: Mahasen

texts.en: Mahasen, an 18-year-old woman living in Ouzai, Mount Lebanon, has been working as a hairdresser for the past two years. Today, Mahasen is hoping to borrow $1,000 in order to buy new equipment to develop her beauty salon.

loans.use: To develop her beauty salon.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Niagnégueton 7 Group

texts.fr:
Niagnéguéton 7 est un regroupement de femmes mariées du hameau Sinsina Sesso de la ville de Koutiala région  de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs enfants, maris, beaux parents, belles sœurs  etc. Elles ont en moyenne 33 ans et au moins 4 enfants.
Elles excellent principalement  dans la culture de l’arachide et du mil.
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe Niagnéguéton 7 ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant quatre ans. Après avoir correctement remboursés  les trois  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur quatrième prêt de campagne.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semences d’arachide et du mil, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture, au grand marché de Koutiala.
 Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Koutiala et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail ou en gros, au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe Niagnéguéton 7 comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 80 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  le remboursement du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Niagnéguéton 7 is a group of married women from the hamlet of Sinsina Sesso of Koutiala City, Sikasso region (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women live in large traditional extended families with their children, husbands, parents-in-law, sisters-in-law, etc. They average 33 years of age and four children each, and they work mainly in the growing of peanuts and millet. Concerned about making their farms profitable, the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program four years ago. After having correctly repaid the three preceding loans, they are now on their fourth farm loan. The current loan will be used to buy a sufficient quantity of seeds for planting peanuts and millet, some minor equipment and supplies, and some fertilizers and the like, for farming. These goods are procured at the grand marketplace of Koutiala. Following the off-season, the crops are stored for a time, so that they gain in value, and then they are sold at the grand marketplace of Koutiala and at surrounding markets, retail or wholesale, in cash transactions. Their customers come generally from large cities. The group members each intend to realize, after selling off their produce, a profit of 80,000 francs CFA that will be use to repay the loan and to cover common family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, seeds, and equipment and supplies

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein, who is a 28-year-old married man with one child living in Ouzai, Mount Lebanon, has been working as a motorcycle repairman since 2005. Today, Hussein is requesting to borrow $1,200 to buy used motorcycles to increase his sales.

loans.use: To increase his sales.

loans.name: Djènèba

texts.fr:
Madame Djénéba C. a 50 ans, veuve et mère de 4 enfants. Elle vit dans une famille polygame avec sa coépouse  et leurs  enfants dans le quartier Kôkô de la préfecture de Koutiala (Région de Sikasso ).  
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’aller  à l’école, elle s’est très vite intéressée aux activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa maman. Après plusieurs activités, elle a opté pour l’achat et la vente des calebasses, domaine dans lequel elles est très appréciée et sollicitée pour la qualité de ses articles.  
Afin de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, Madame a fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis 2005.  Après  4 prêts  solidaires (prêt de groupe) tous remboursés correctement, elle est à son  premier prêt  individuel.
Djénéba compte utiliser ce prêt pour se constituer des stocks de calebasses. Elle s’approvisionne dans les villages environnants auprès des producteurs et effectue ses ventes en gros à Abidjan (capitale de  la  Côte  d’Ivoire)  et en détail dans les différents quartiers de Koutiala à une clientèle  composée de revendeurs, de femmes et hommes et les ventes sont réalisées au comptant et quelques fois à crédit.  
Avec ce prêt, Madame Djénéba compte réaliser un  bénéfice mensuel  de 150 000 FCFA  qu’elle utilisera pour le remboursement des taux d’intérêts du prêt, la prise  en charge des besoins de sa famille  et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Djénéba C., age 50, is a widow and the mother of four children. She lives in a polygamous family with her co-wife and their children in the Kôkô district of Koutiala prefecture (Region of Sikasso). Not having had the chance to go to school, she soon became interested in earning an income at her mother's side. After several kinds of work, Djénéba opted for buying and selling calabash bowls, a domain in which she is highly valued and in great demand for the quality of her goods. To satisfy her burgeoning customer base, Djénéba turned toward the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in 2005. After four solidarity loans (group loans), all correctly repaid, she is now on her first individual loan. She intends to use this loan to replenish her stock of calabash bowls. Supplies are procured from producers in the surrounding villages. Sales are made wholesale in Abidjan (capital of Côte d’Ivoire) and retail in the different districts of Koutiala. Her customers are composed of retailers, women, and men. Transactions are in cash and sometimes on credit. With this loan, she intends to realize a monthly profit of 150,000 francs CFA that she will use to make loan interest payments, to support her family, and to invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy calabash bowls

loans.name: Rasha

texts.en: Rasha, a 20-year-old woman living in Chiyah, Mount Lebanon, has been working as an interior designer for the past two years. Today, Rasha is requesting to borrow $800 to buy a computer to be able to expand her career.

loans.use: To buy a computer.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali, who is a 32-year-old married man with one child living in Al Mrayjeh, Mount Lebanon, has been working as a taxi driver since 2005 servicing the surrounding areas. Today, Ali is requesting to borrow $1,200 to buy new wheels for his car.

loans.use: To buy new wheels for his car.

loans.name: Salimata

texts.fr:
En instance de divorce et mère d’un enfant, Madame Salimata D. a 34 ans. Elle vit actuellement chez ses parents dans le quartier Kouloukoro de la préfecture de Koutiala (troisième région du Mali)
N’ayant pas eu la chance de continuer ses études primaires par manque de moyen de ses parents, Salimata n’a pas pris du temps à entreprendre des activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa maman. Salimata évolue seule maintenant  depuis 10 ans. Elle a choisi comme créneau l’achat vente d’articles divers tels les pagnes wax,  les bijoux,  les chaussures etc. Cette  activité lui est  très rentable, car elle est très sollicitée par les femmes de la ville de Koutiala. 
Dans le souci  d’augmenter son fonds de commerce  et satisfaire sa clientèle en qualité, Madame décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso en  2007.  Après 2  prêts  solidaires ( prêt de groupe ) tous payés correctement, elle est à son premier  prêt  individuel. 
Elle compte acheter, 40 colliers et 10 pièces de pagnes wax. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako et souvent au Sénégal  et effectue sa vente dans la ville de Koutiala à une clientèle composée  de jeunes filles et de femmes mariées  au comptant et à crédit.  
Salimata espère réaliser  un bénéfice mensuel de 80.000 FCFA  qu’elle envisage utiliser pour le remboursement des d’intérêts du prêt,  entretenir son enfant  et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
