Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For seeds and seedlings

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
“Hard work is the key to successful living,” says Elena.

Elena is a responsible mother and entrepreneur who lives in Barangay Bonfal Proper Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Vicente and they are blessed with three children. The eldest is now in secondary level education and the two youngest are in elementary level education. Because of financial difficulty, they are struggling to earn a living and to support the studies of their children.

Vicente is a farmer, and he plants a variety of vegetables twice a year. Elena is engaged in managing a general store. She acquires her products from Nueva Vizcaya Agricultural Terminal (NVAT) and sells them at retail prices. She is requesting to borrow PHP 15,000 as additional working capital for her business. She hopes that with help from this loan, she may further provide for much of their household’s expenses and for the studies of their children.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Chou

texts.en: Mr. Chou H. is 60 years old and is married to Mrs. Mom Houn (pictured). They have one child. Chou H. generates his daily income by working as a furniture maker. He usually buys wood to make tables, chairs, and windows and sells them for a profit. On the other hand, he also has been hired by neighbors in order to build their house. As another income source, his wife works selling Khmer noodles in the village. Chou H. hopes to earn additional income by raising pigs because he has previous experience in this activity. Due to the lack of capital, he has decided to seek a loan from Kiva in order to buy piglets to raise.

loans.use: To buy piglets to raise.

loans.name: Channy

texts.en: Mrs. Channy L. is 37 years old and she lives in Kaoh Prak village in Kandal province. She is a Chinese noodle seller in the local market. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more noodles and ingredients to add to her soup to make it more delicious. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family’s living conditions with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Sout Rous, is a policeman in a local district. Mrs. Channy L. has two children who are attending the local school. The other four people in the picture is a group guarantee.

loans.use: Purchasing more noodles and ingredients for soup making business.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en: Erlinda is popularly known by her nickname, “Linda”. She was born on November 8, 1958 at Barangay Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Marcelo and they are blessed with two children, Christopher and Carlo. The children have both finished a vocational course (driver mechanic) and now work as driver of a passenger jeepney. Erlinda manages a vending business for vegetables, fruits and sometimes meat and fish. She is requesting to borrow PHP 8,000 as additional capital for her simple vending business. Her stall is located just in front of their house. She hopes her business will become successful as she continues becoming part of this lending plan and by patiently doing her best to sustain her vending business.

loans.use: Business Capital for fruit and vegetable business.

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
“My ambition is simply to be a successful businesswoman,” says Lilia M..

Lilia is married to Jaime M.. They raised their family at Barangay Bonfal Proper Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. With their continuous support and sacrifices, most of their children have finished their studies in college and some have already gotten married. 
Farming is their main source of income. They plant a variety of vegetables twice a year. Lilia also sells their vegetables in the local market so they can get the retail price for as much of the crop as possible. She is borrowing an amount of PHP 12,000 as additional working capital. She believes that someday she will be successful by relying on her continued patience and sacrifices.

loans.use: Business Capital for faming business.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith T. is from the village of Yahong,Tudela,Misamis Occidental. She is 40 years old. Judith is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Judith owns & operates a general store. She sells a variety of different products in the local community. Judith has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2,000.00 PHP a month for these activities.

In May 2009, Judith joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Judith is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Judith from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products for her store.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en: Marites A. aims to make her business grow in order to send her five children to school and also to repair her home. Her family is poor but Marites believes that their poverty is not a hindrance to success. She is determined to reach her goal in life to provide for her family, especially her children. They live in a rural community located Barangay Murong Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Marvel and they are blessed with five children. Two of the children are in high school while the others are currently in elementary school. At present, they are struggling financially but they keep trying their best to work had and earn a living. Marvel works as a janitor while Marites earns a living by selling vegetables and balut. She is requesting a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 as additional working capital for her vending business. With the extra capital she hopes to increase her business and earn a higher income.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Vuthy's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Vuthy P. is a group leader of three members who all live in Chheu Teal village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Mao Bophea, are farmers who own a small piece of land, used for cultivating rice. After they finish their plantation, they are laborers hired by the other villagers. Even though they try to work hard, they still earn less income than is required to support their family’s expenses. Thus, Mrs. Vuthy P. decided to ask for a loan to buy bananas to resell to earn more money to support her family. She hopes this new business will succeed and improve her family’s living. She is 31 years old and the mother of three children, two are attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study. The man in the picture is a guarantor.

Two members in this group are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy bananas to resell to earn more money to support her family.

loans.name: Tresita

texts.en:
Tresita B. is from the village of Yahong, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 54 years old. Tresita is married and has 7 adult-aged children. To make a living, Tresita owns a general store. She sells a variety of different products to the local community. Tresita has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 1,500.00 PHP a month for these activities.

In May 2009, Tresita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Tresita is requesting a new loan of PHP 4000. These funds will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Tresita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products for her business.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy J. is already 41 years old. She is a simple resident of Barangay Murong Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Edmer J. and is blessed with six children. Four of her children have graduated from high school but did not pursue college because they cannot finance their studies. Some of them help their father in farming. Nancy also lets them do their best to have a better future.

Nancy is engaged in a buy and sell business of vegetables in the village in order to help her husband provide for their daily living expenses. She is requesting to take a loan from lenders amounting to PHP 8,000 as additional working capital. Through this loan, Nancy will able to buy more and different vegetables to increase her daily income. She hopes her business becomes progressive for a better living.

loans.use: Business Capital.

loans.name: Unelyn

texts.en:
Unelyn M. is from the village of Tinacla-an, Clarin,Misamis Occidenta. She is 30 years old. Unelyn is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Unelyn owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Unelyn has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Unelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Unelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase ingredients needed to make products for sale.

Unelyn is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Unelyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Pos

texts.en:
Pictured is Mrs. Pos P., 40, who lives in the province of Kompong Tom, where she and her husband earn a living as rice cultivators. As the other source of the family income, Pos P.'s husband drives a motorbike taxi. The couple has two children who are school-age.

Recently, Pos P.'s husband hasn't been able to attract as many customers as before because his motorbike is not comfortable. That is why Pos P. has decided to ask for a US$ 200 loan to add to her savings to purchase a motorbike to replace the existing one.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to replace their existing one

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
“Having faith in God and one's own abilities will lead to a successful living,” is the motivation of Remedios A..

She completed a vocational course in sewing and is happily married to Angelito A.. They live in the rural community of Barangay Murong Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya, with their two children. Remedios operates a village store and hopes that the business will someday grow.

Remedios is requesting a loan from ASKI and Kiva Lenders amounting to PHP 10,000 as additional working capital for her business. Her husband's occupation is farming and she is doing her best to assist him with their farm inputs needs. Her weekly income from the business also will be saved for her weekly payments to ASKI.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie is a farmer; she and her family plant rice and vegetables twice a year. Furthermore, Rosemarie also is engaged in vegetable vending to earn additional income for the education of her children since education nowadays is very costly. She hopes to borrow additional capital from lenders to acquire more products for her to sell. She is applying for a loan amounting to PHP 9,000 as additional working capital to generate higher income to continue sending her children to school regularly.

Rosemarie or “Belen” as she is commonly called, lives in the village of Barangay Murong Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Reynaldo S. and they were blessed with three children. Their eldest is now in second year college, their second child is a college freshman, and their youngest is already in the last year of his secondary schooling. The couple has fought through the hardships of life to send their children to school, as it is a very high priority for them.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Visitacion

texts.en:
Visitacion B. is a responsible mother to her four children. She is married to Virgilio and is living in Barangay Murong Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 54 years old and her husband is 60 years old. The main occupation in the village is farming. Due to our economic crisis, all of their children were not able to pursue their studies in college, however, they are working hard to earn their daily living.

Visitacion continuously cultivates their farm and manages their small general store at home. She hopes to maintain her business by having enough capital to use in the improvement of her businesses, especially her store that is a great help in providing for their daily needs. Visitacion is applying for a loan amounting to PHP 9,000 as additional working capital for the improvement of her store.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Tashbubi

texts.ru: Ташбуви женщина 48 лет. Замужем и имеет 3-х детей. Занимается откормом и продажей скота вместе с мужем. Ташбуви откармливает скот дома, и когда скот будет готов, муж Ташбуви продает их на скотном рынке. Ташбуви кредитуется в нашей организации 1 год. Она успешно закончила предыдущий займ, и теперь хочет взять очередной займ. Ташбуви планирует увеличить количество своего скота и тем увеличить прибыль своей семьи. Ташбуви очень нравится условия нашего кредитования, и она рада, что есть такие организации, поддерживающие общество.
texts.en:
Tashbubi is a 48-year-old woman. She is married with three children. She and her husband work fattening and selling cattle. Tashbubi fattens the cattle at home, and when the cattle is ready, her husband sells them in the cattle market. Tashbubi has financed her business through our organization for a year. She successfully paid off the previous loan, and now wishes to take out another loan. Tashbubi plans to increase the quantity of the cattle she sells and thereby increase the family's profit. Tashbubi really appreciates our credit terms, and she is glad that there are organizations like this supporting society.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fattening and selling livestock

loans.name: Barotboy

texts.ru: Баротбою 44 года. Он женат и отец 5-х детей. Его жена нигде не работает. Она сидит дома и делает домашнюю работу, кормит скот. Баротбой занимается откормом и продажей скота. Наступление лета для Баротбоя – это сезон закупа скота, потому, что летом скот и его корм стоит дешево. И для откорма скота не надо много тратиться. Скот ест горную траву, и Баротбой экономит на корме скота. С наступлением зимы Баротбой продает часть откормившегося скота. Но он не покупает скот. Он покупает корм, для откорма оставшегося скота.
texts.en:
Barotboy is 44 years old, married and the father of five children. His wife is not employed; she stays at home to do housework and feed the livestock. Barotboy raises and sells cattle. For Barotboy the beginning of summer means it's the season to buy animals, since in summer they and their feed is inexpensive. Beside, he doesn't need to spend much on feed because the livestock eat the mountain grasses. When winter begins Barotboy sells part of the finished herd, but does not buy more. He buys feed for the remaining animals.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising and selling livestock

loans.name: Zebo

texts.ru: Самадова Зебо, молодая женщина 25 лет ,имеет одного ребёнка.Зебо вместе со свекровью занимается шитьём и продажей халатов и платьев. Она закончила курсы шитья женской одежды и приступила к самостоятельной деятельности. У неё много клиентов в районе Мастчох, которые покупают у неё её платья и халаты.Зебо хочет в кредит купить вышивальную машинку и выбивать на национальных платьях вышивки. Сейчас у нас очень модно носить платья с вышивками. На снимке Зебо в день подачи заявки на кредит.
texts.en:
Zebo S. is a young, 25 year old woman with one child. She and her mother-in-law have a business sewing and selling robes and dresses. She began independent work after completing courses on sewing women's clothing. She has many customers in the Mastchoh district for her robes and dresses. Zebo would like to use a loan to buy an embroidery machine for embroidering traditional dresses. It's popular right now to have dresses with embroidery. In the photograph Zebo is pictured the day she applied for the loan.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sewing and sale of dresses and robes

loans.name: Rustam

texts.ru: Рустам мужчина торгующий на рынке Гафурова запасными частями автомашин и велосипедов.Он получает товар от поставщиков, которые привозят из Китая.Его торговля проходит стабильно, поэтому для поддержки товарооборота Рустам хочет получить повторный кредит.На снимке Рустам в день подачи заявки на займ.Он арендует небольшой ларёк в центре рынка "Фаровон".Рустама удовлетворяют все условия Фонда и он благодарен всем инвесторам за поддержку и финансирование.
texts.en:
Rustam is a vendor at the Gafurova market, where he rents a small stall and sells spare parts for cars and bicycles. The goods come from suppliers who import them from China. His sales have been stable, and to sustain business he would like to take out a new loan. In the photograph Rustam is pictured the day he applied for the loan. Rustam has met all the Fund's conditions and he is grateful for all of the investors' support and financing.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Spare part sales

loans.name: Alichon

texts.ru: Аличон - кредитор в Микроинвест уже третий год.Каждый займ он берёт для расширения своего бизнеса, торговли запасными частями для автомашин.Аличон ездит за товаром в Истаравшан и закупает на оптовом рынке по оптовым ценам и с наценкой продаёт на рынке " Фаровон" города Гафурова.Для завоза различных замков и запчастей  Аличон хочет получить повторный кредит. На фото Аличон на месте бизнеса.
texts.en:
Alichon has been a MicroInvest borrower for three years already. He takes out every loan in order to grow his business, the sale of spare auto parts. Alichon travels for products to Istaravshan and purchases them at the wholesale market at wholesale prices and sells them with a markup at the “Farovon” market in Gafurov. Alichon would like to get a repeat loan to purchase various locks and spare parts. In the photo is Alichon at his place of business.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sale of auto parts

loans.name: Hamid

texts.ru: Хамид Кузиев торгует на рынке "Фаровон" города Гафурова.Для расширения бизнеса Хамид уже второй год получает кредиты в Микроинвесте.Хамид ездит за товаром в Истаравшан на оптовый рынок.Торгует на рынке каждый день.Его запасные части в основном для сантехников, поэтому у него много своих постоянных клиентов, которые покупают у него товар.Для пополнения товарооборота Хамид хочет получить следующий кредит.
texts.en:
Hamid K. sells at the Farovon market in Gafurov. Hamid has been using loans from Microinvest to expand his business for the past two years. He travels to the wholesale market in Istaravshan to buy merchandise, and sells at the market each day. The spare parts he has are mostly for plumbers, so he has many regular customers. Hamid would like to obtain another loan to use to increase sales.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sale of spare plumbing parts

loans.name: Chi's Group

texts.en:
This is a small group comprised of five borrowers, all of whom live in the province of Siem Reap. Its leader, Mrs. Chi T., 39, is a widowed mother who has three children. All three of them are single and attend school. She usually sells fresh fish that she buys in bulk from a wholesale supplier and then retails them for a profit in the local market. In the business, Chi T. has attracted a number of customers who come to buy her fish because she has a skill in communication and sells at a better price in the market. In order to meet more of her customer's needs, she would like a loan to accrue a quantity of fresh fish to sell. The other four borrowers who have joined this loan:
Mrs. K. will be using a loan to buy more tools for her fishing business.
Mrs. R. is fish catcher, who is asking for a loan to purchase a boat to use for fishing.
Mr. C. is a fish-carrying worker, who is applying for a loan to repair his old house.
Mrs. T. will be using the loan money to support her fishing business activities.

loans.use: To purchase a quantity of fresh fish to sell.

loans.name: Ouyètiè 1 (On Se Connais). Group

texts.fr:
Ouyètiè 1 est un regroupement de femmes mariées du village de Nitabogoro de la ville de Koutiala région de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs enfants, maris, beaux parents, belles sœurs  etc. Elles ont en moyenne 30 ans et au moins 6 enfants.
Elles font plusieurs cultures mais se sont spécialisée dans celle de l’arachide.
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe Ouyètiè 1 ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt, elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semences d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture, au grand marché de Koutiala ville. 
Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Koutiala et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe Ouyètiè 1 comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 65 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Ouyètiè 1 is a group of married women who live in the Nitabogoro neighborhood in the city of Koutiala (Sikasso Region, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in large extended traditional families with their children, husbands, in-laws, etc. They average 30 years of age, and have at least 6 children. They cultivate various crops, but specialize in peanuts. Eager to make their cultures profitable, the members of the group Ouyètiè 1 decided to join the loan program of Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso, two years ago. After having repaid the first loan without problem, they are now seeking their second farming loan.

The new loan will be used to buy, at the grand market in Koutiala, a sufficient quantity of peanuts seeds, small materials, and fertilizers for the fields. After the rainy season, crops are stored for a while to gain market value, before being sold at the grand market in Koutiala and in the surrounding villages, retail (often wholesale) and for cash, to a clientele usually coming from the larger cities.

After selling their production, the members of the group Ouyètiè 1 count on turning a profit of XOF 65'000 (ca US$ 140) each, to be used to repay the loan and to pay for the daily expenses of the family.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy peanuts seeds, small materials, and fertilizers for the fields

loans.name: Nov

texts.en: Nov T. is 65 years old and has owned a medium house located in the Pursat Province where she has lived with her family members for years. She and her husband currently cultivate different crops on their one hectare piece of farmland that was inherited from their grandparents. The couple has six children; three of whom are employed in different jobs. Since 1990, the family has been farming and they also hired the neighbor's oxen to help with plowing their farmland. Nov T. hopes to reduce the cost of plowing by using loan money to buy a cow. She will be able to rent out the cow to other farmers for a profit and she will also raise its offspring.

loans.use: To buy a cow.

loans.name: Ouyètiè 2 Group

texts.fr:
Ouyètiè 2 est un regroupement de femmes mariées du village de Nitabogoro de la ville de Koutiala région de Sikasso(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs enfants, maris, beaux parents, belles sœurs  etc. Elles ont en moyenne 29 ans et au moins 6 enfants.
Elles excellent principalement  dans la culture de l’arachide et du haricot.
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe Ouyètiè 2 ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant  2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt, elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semences d’arachide, de haricot, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture, au grand marché de Koutiala ville.  
Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Koutiala et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant à une clientèle généralement  constituée de revendeurs  venant des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe Ouyètiè 2 comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 65 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Ouyètiè 2 is a group of married women who live in the Nitabogoro neighborhood in the city of Koutiala (Sikasso Region, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in large extended traditional families with their children, husbands, in-laws, etc. They average 29 years of age, and have at least 6 children. They mostly specialize in cultivating peanuts and beans. Eager to make their cultures profitable, the members of the group Ouyètiè 2 decided to join the loan program of Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso, two years ago. After having repaid the first loan without problem, they are now seeking their second farming loan. The new loan will be used to buy, at the grand market in Koutiala, a sufficient quantity of peanuts seeds, beans, small materials, and fertilizers for the fields. After the rainy season, crops are stored for a while to gain market value, before being sold at the grand market in Koutiala and in the surrounding villages, retail (often wholesale) and for cash, to a clientele of resellers usually coming from the larger cities. After selling their production, the members of the group Ouyètiè 2 count on turning a profit of XOF 65'000 (ca US$ 140) each, to be used to repay the loan and to pay for the daily expenses of the family.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy peanuts seeds, beans, small materials, and fertilizers for the fields

loans.name: Ouyètiè 3 Group

texts.fr:
Ouyètiè 3 est un regroupement de femmes mariées du village de Nitabogoro de la ville de Koutiala région de Sikasso(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies et ont en moyenne 34 ans et au moins 6 enfants. 
Elles  se sont connues par des relations de voisinage et professionnelle et font essentiellement  la culture du mil.
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ouyètiè3 ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt, elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semences de mil, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture, au grand marché de Koutiala ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Koutiala et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe Ouyètiè 3 comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 65 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Ouyètiè 3 is a group of married women who live in the Nitabogoro neighborhood in the city of Koutiala (Sikasso Region, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in large extended traditional families with their children, husbands, in-laws, etc. They average 34 years of age, and have at least 6 children. They got acquainted through bonds of neighborhood and professional connexions, and mostly cultivate millet. Eager to make their cultures profitable, the members of the group Ouyètiè 3 decided to join the loan program of Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso, two years ago. After having repaid the first loan without problem, they are now seeking their second farming loan.

The new loan will be used to buy, at the grand market in Koutiala, a sufficient quantity of millet seeds, small materials, and fertilizers for the fields. After the rainy season, crops are stored for a while to gain market value, before being sold at the grand market in Koutiala and in the surrounding villages, retail (often wholesale) and for cash, to a clientele usually coming from the larger cities.

After selling their production, the members of the group Ouyètiè 3 count on turning a profit of XOF 65'000 (ca US$ 140) each, to be used to repay the loan and to pay for the daily expenses of the family.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy millets seeds, small materials, and fertilizers for the fields

loans.name: Ouyètiè 4 Group

texts.fr:
Ouyètiè 4 est un regroupement de femmes mariées du village de Nitabogoro de la ville de Koutiala région de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 32 ans et au moins 4 enfants. 
Elles excellent principalement  dans la culture de l’arachide et du mil.
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe Ouyètiè 4 ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt, elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semences d’arachide et de mil, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture, au grand marché de Koutiala. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Koutiala et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe Ouyètiè 4 comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice moyen de 65 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Ouyètiè 4 is a group of married women from the village of Nitabogoro of the town of Koutiala, Sikasso region (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in big traditional families and are on average 32 with at least 4 children. They mainly excel in cultivating peanuts and millet.

With the intention of making their agricultural businesses profitable, the members of the Ouyètiè 4 group decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso two years ago. After having correctly reimbursed their first loan, they are on their second rural loan.

The present loan will be used to buy a sufficient quantity of peanut and millet seeds, other small necessities for farming, and entrants for these crops, in the big market of Koutiala. After the rainy season, the harvests are stocked for a certain period so that they have more value before being sold at the big market of Koutiala and in the surrounding markets, retail (often wholesale) and for cash to a clientele mostly coming from the big towns.

Each of the members of the Ouyètiè 4 group expects, after their crops are sold, to make an average profit of 65,000 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the loan and for current family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of entrants, seeds, and minor agricultural materials

loans.name: Ouyètiè  5 (On Se Connais) Group

texts.fr:
Ouyètiè 5 est un regroupement de femmes mariées du village de Nitabogoro de la ville de Koutiala région de Sikasso(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs enfants, maris, beaux parents, belles soeurs  etc. Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans et au moins 5 enfants. 
Elles excellent principalement  dans la culture de l’arachide et du mil.
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe Ouyètiè 5 ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt, elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semences d’arachide et de mil, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture, au grand marché de Koutiala. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Koutiala et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe Ouyètiè 5 comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice moyen de 55 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Ouyètiè 5 is a group of married women of the village of Nitabogoro in Koutiala City, Sikasso region (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in large traditional extended families with their children, husbands, parents-in-law, sisters-in-law, etc. They average 35 years of age and at least 5 children each. They work mainly in growing peanuts and millet. Concerned about making their farms profitable, the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program two years ago. After having correctly repaid the first loan, they are now on their second farm loan. The current loan will be used to buy a sufficient quantity of seeds for planting peanuts and millet; some minor supplies and equipment; and some fertilizers and the like, for farming. These items are gotten at the grand marketplace of Koutiala. After wintering, the crops are stored for a time, so that they gain in value. And then they are sold at the same marketplace and at surrounding marketplaces at the retail level (often wholesale), in cash transactions with customers generally from large cities. The group members each intend to realize, after selling their agricultural products, an average profit of 55,000 francs CFA that will be used to repay the loan and to cover common family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilzers, seeds, and minor supplies and equipment

loans.name: Karomat

texts.ru: Кодирова  Каромат женщина , которая кредитуется в Микроинвест уже третий год. Она использует кредит на расширение бизнеса , торговли продуктов питания. Её точка торговли находится в городе Худжанде, при входе в городскую больницу. На следующий займ она хочет пополнить свой товарооборот напитками и мороженым. На снимке Каромат на месте бизнеса.
texts.en:
Karomat K. is a woman who has been a client of Microinvest's for three years already. She uses loans to expand her business selling groceries. Her vendor space is in the city of Khudjand, near the entrance to the city hospital. She would like to use the next loan to expand her inventory of drinks and ice cream. The photograph shows Karomat at her business.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Food sales

loans.name: Muhabbat

texts.ru: Мухаббат – женщина , которая целыми днями торгует при входе в городскую больницу. Она продаёт фруктами и овощами. Полученный кредит она хочет использовать на закуп помидоров и различных фруктов. Она очень вежливая и доброжелательная продавщица, у которой много постоянных клиентов. На снимке Мухаббат на месте бизнеса.
texts.en:
Muhabbat is a woman who sells all day at the entrance to the city hospital. She sells fruit and vegetables. She wants to take out a loan to buy tomatoes and fruit. She is a very polite and good-natured saleswoman who has many regular customers. The picture is of Muhabbat in her place of business.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Selling fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Selestina

texts.en:
Selestina has been a clothes seller in the Kola neighborhood of Morogoro for 20 years. She belongs to Tupendane group loan (Group code 2001/2).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately  $530. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  

She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes for resale. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to increase her business.

Selestina is 45 years old, married, and has five  children: aged 27, 25, 20, 16, 8 and 7. She also cares for two dependents.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Moshi

texts.en:
Moshi has been a sausage seller in the Kola neighborhood of Morogoro for 2 years. She belongs to Railway Corter group loan (Group code 2053).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately $90. Every day she works at her business for 8 hours.  

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more sausage for resale. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to expand her business.  

Moshi is 39 years old, married, and has two  children: ages 14 and 10.

loans.use: To buy more sausage for resale, to expand her business.

loans.name: Islaha Primary School, Makeni Group

texts.en:
These are teachers of the Islaha Primary School, Makeni. This school was established in 1986 and gained government approval in 1996. Built by the Islaha Mission, a local, non-governmental organization, the school has a total of fifteen staff and 317 pupils.

Many schools in Sierra Leone complain about the lack of adequate building, seating and learning materials. The Islaha Primary School is one of the worse examples – the Islaha mission lacks overseas sponsorship like other Christian/Muslim missions. The school is still in its rudimentary stages. Though they use mud bricks, they have yet to complete the building process.

Momodu A.C B. (back row, second from right) is the Head Teacher at the school and head of this group. Momodu is 36. He was born in Malimamy village, about thirty miles from Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. He is married to a businesswoman and they have a nine-year-old child who is in primary school.

Momodu has been a teacher for nine years now. He will use this loan to complete the payment of a piece of land for which he has made a deposit.  Buying a plot of land will improve his life, he tells me. At least, this will be a very good starting point for Mr. B. in achieving his dream of building himself a permanent residence.

loans.use: Purchase a piece of land for housing construction.

loans.name: Mwanaidi

texts.en: For the last two years, Mwanaidi has made a living selling fish in the Kola neighborhood of Morogoro. She is a member of the Railway Corter loan group, and currently earns about $175 a month by working eight hours a day. Mwanaidi is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more fish to sell and expand her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her income will increase. Mwanaidi is 24  years old and married.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell and to expand her business.

loans.name: Ketty

texts.en: For the last five years, Ketty has made a living selling fish in the Kola neighborhood of Morogoro. She is a member of the Waridi Loan Group, and makes about $175 a month by working at her business for 12 hours a day.  Ketty is applying for her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more fish to resell, and hopes that this loan will allow her to increase her profits and expand her business.  Ketty is 50 years old, single, and has one child, who is 32 years old. She is also responsible for the care of one dependent.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell and expand her business.

loans.name: Kojo

texts.en:
Kojo J. makes a living selling beer, and has applied for this loan to buy more beer in bulk to sell to her customers.  She is 30 years old and married. Her husband is employed as a driver and they have three children, all of whom are in school. With the additional income made possible by this loan, she hopes to open a bar. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to buy more beer to sell to her customers

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji J. makes a living selling groundnut paste, and has applied for this loan to buy more groundnuts to make into paste. She is 39 years old and married. Her husband is an information technology officer, and they have two children, both of whom are in school. With the additional income made possible by this loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to buy more groundnut to make into paste and sell

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria A. is 32 years old, married and has four children. She makes a living selling fresh and smoked fish. Victoria has applied for this loan to buy more fish to sell, and wishes to extend her sincere thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Uamsho Group

texts.en:
Aziza has been a chicken and chapati seller in the Kola neighborhood of Morogoro for two years. She belongs to the Uamsho loan group (group code 2049/05). She currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately $90. She works at her business for eight hours every day.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can expand her business by buying more chicken for resale. She is hoping that through this loan her profit will increase and her business will grow.

Aziza is 44 years old and married with three children, ages 25, 15, and 12. She also cares for two additional dependents. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members: Hadija, Husna, Rehema, and Maria. Each woman also has her own small business in Morogoro.

loans.use: To buy more buy more chicken for resale.

loans.name: Ritta

texts.en:
Ritta has been a food vendor in the Kola neighborhood of Morogoro for one year. She belongs to the Waridi loan group (group code 2045/08). She currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately $80. She works at her business for 12 hours every day.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items, like rice and bananas, for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Ritta is 45 years old and single with four children, ages 21, 16, 12, and 8. She also cares for three dependents.

loans.use: To buy more food items, like rice and bananas, for her business.

loans.name: Cándida

texts.en:
Mrs. Candida is a 48 year old business woman. She is married to Mr. Dionisio, who is 51 and works as a bricklayer. They have five children. José is 27 and works laying bricks with his father. Nancy is a 25 year old teacher. Juana is 24 and works in Spain. Enrique is 19 and Juan is 12 and attends sixth grade.

Mrs. Cándida began her activity in 2006, with much effort and help from her family, so that they could progress forward. Today she has a very well-supported small grocery store.

She applied for the loan to buy construction materials to make a new commercial space because her current one is too small. She hopes to finish her new space and increase her merchandise. Through this she hopes to increase her sales and income and the well-being of her family.

loans.use: To buy construction materials to make a new commercial space.

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan R. sells plates and cups in a shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more goods to sell. Juan is 29 years old and married. Her husband is a driver. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Isoken

texts.en: Isoken E. sells provisions and drinks. She is 50 years old and married with seven children. She hopes for a loan in the amount of N50,000 to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther O. sells foodstuffs. She is 42 years old and married with two children. She hopes for a loan in the amount of N50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Adot

texts.en:
Adot P. sells beer at home and is requesting a loan to open up a bar at the market to increase her sales. Adot is 40 years old and married. Her husband is a security guard. She has three children, who all attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children's school fees.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open a bar.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase goods for making food products

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma has sold breakfast food in the Kola neighborhood of Morogoro for four years. She belongs to the Mzabibu loan group (group code 2015/07). She currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately $125. Every day, she works at her business for four hours.

She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more breakfast food items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Fatuma is 40 years old. She is separated from her husband and has four children, ages 20, 15, 12, and 10.

loans.use: To buy more breakfast food items to sell.

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth has owned a small general store in the Kola neighborhood of Morogoro for six months. She belongs to the Waridi loan group (group code 2045/07). She currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately $40. Every day she works at her business for 16 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more wheat flour, soap, rice, and other items to add her current stock. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Janeth is 32 years old, married, and has six children, ages 14, 12, 10, 8, and 6 years, and one just 6 months old. She also cares for two additional dependents.

loans.use: To buy more wheat flour, soap, rice, and other items.

loans.name: Andrea

texts.en:
Andrea M. is in the business of selling beer. She is requesting a loan to buy more beer to sell.

She is 45 years old and is married. Her husband is a security guard. She has two children who go to school.

With the extra profits from her loan, Andrea hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

----------------------------------- BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Buy more beer to sell.

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en: Blessing R. is 30 years old and married with four children.  She sells provisions, drinks and foodstuffs.  Blessing seeks a loan of N70, 000 to purchase more itemsto sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase more provisions and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Kuña Aty Group

texts.en:
The committee for women is named Kuña Aty and is led by Juliana B. D. S., who makes handicrafts. She was able to form a group of 17 women, who are now on their second loan cycle.

The average amount of credit given to each participant is 470,000 Gs, which goes to their different activities. All of the women do their activities, collect funds and help each other to accomplish their common goals.

They actively participate in weekly meetings and work as a team while demonstrating a spirit of comradeship and support. Here is a list of members and their primary business activities:

1 Juliana B. D. SotelHandicrafts 2 Celsa R. Diner 3 Ma. Carmen C. -Drink sales 4 Flora B. - Making and selling cigarrettes 5 Flavia C. - Small grocery store 6 Alberta R. - Dressmaker 7 Mercedes I. - Hair salon 8 Agueda L. - Tobacco sales 9 Jazmín S. - Honey sales 10 Miguela N. - Coal sales 11 Victoria D. - Tobacco sales 12 Ma. Lina G. - Small grocery store 13 Lilian B. - Drink sales 14 Ma. Nicolasa B. - Hair salon 15 Emilia R. - Dressmaker 16 Cipriana P. - Small grocery store 17 Celina B. - Coal sales

loans.use: Purchase merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Hila

texts.en:
Hila R. selling beer in her bar and is requesting a loan to purchase more crates of beer to sell. Hila is 40 years old and married to a peasant husband. They have two children who go to school.

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house and pay school fees for her children.

---------------------------------------- BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase more beer to sell.

loans.name: Renacer Group

texts.en:
The committee of women named “Renacer” (“Reborn”), formed on January 17th, 2009 thanks to Mrs. Daniela R. D., the current Director of Finances. She works making and selling food. She contacted the advisor in order to enter into a committee of enterprising women. Once she became a member of the program, she was able to gather 16 women, who are now working in their second cycle in the program. 

The average credit give to each participant is 480,000 Gs, which goes to different activities such as the sale of: food, hardware, grocery store items, clothing, lingerie, fruit, vegetables, meat, and honey cakes. 

The “Reborn” group is an excellent group whose members work supportively with each other. All of the participants attend weekly meetings and do their activities for the well-being of the group. 

1. Carmen P. - Dressmaker
2. Daniela R. D. - Diner
3. Josefina R. - Grocery store 
4. María M. - Pig farmer 
5. Justa B. - Drink sales 
6. Josefa A. - Cake sales 
7. Gladys A. - Clothing sales 
8. Lourdes M. - Candy sales 
9. Cynthia N. - Clothing and honey-cake sales 
10. Gloria P. - Drink sales 
11. Liliana A. - Clothing sales 
12. Elsi A. - Food sales 
13. Inocencia A. - Small grocery store 
14. Aureliana A. - Drink sales 
15. Teresa G. - Meat and vegetable sales 
16. Lorena P. - Food sales

loans.use: To purchase items for their individual enterprises

loans.name: Saldivar Poty Group

texts.en:
The committee of women named Saldivar Poty was formed on March 22, 2007, thanks to Mrs. Esther Silver, who makes and sells cleaning products. She contacted an advisor during a weekly meeting that took place in the neighborhood, inquiring about how to form a committee of enterprising women. Once part of the program, she was able to group 15 women, which are now working together in their 8th cycle within the program. 

During the course of time, the group has experienced some inconveniences, as the daughter of the General Director was admitted to the hospital, and other participants were sick and bedridden. However, they responded without a single problem in repayments, and in this way the group has been able to progress, continuing with the program until now. 

The average credit give per participant is 735,000 Gs, which goes to many different activities such as the sale of: food, hardware, grocery store products, clothing, lingerie, cosmetics, fruit, vegetables, cleaning products, crochet, etc. 

All of them do their own activities in order to earn money, and mutually help each other achieve common objectives within the group and with the Paraguayan Foundation. They participate actively in weekly meetings and do an impeccably supportive job. 

1. Ma. Esther S. - Cleaning product sales 
2. Justina L. - Food sales 
3. Rosalina B. - Cleaning product sales 
4. Gladys N. - Clothing sales 
5. Juana C. - Lingerie sales 
6. Eustacia O. - Sale of fruit and vegetables 
7. Miryan C. - Cleaning product sales 
8. Francisca B. - Clothing and bag sales 
9. Marlene B. - Hardware store 
10. Ma. Mabelín L. - Polyethylene sales 
11. Dominga P. - Cleaning product sales, and crochet 
12. Marcelina C. - Clothing sales 
13. Rosa Ortiz - Sale of fruit and vegetables 
14. Evarista F. - Lingerie sales 
15. Johana L. - Small grocery store

loans.use: To purchase items for their individual businesses

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es: La Señora María Elena M. tiene 60 años, su estado civil es casada. María tiene 4 hijos y todos trabajan de manera independiente. La actividad económica es una pulpería. Hace más de 9 años que se dedica a esta humilde actividad. Inicio por medio de una amiga quien le enseño a salir adelante, esto le ayudo a María a ser una persona luchadora, además cabe resaltar, que con la edad que posee no le impide tener ese amino de alegría para servirle a sus clientes. El destino de este financiamiento es para capital de trabajo en la compra de granos básicos, pan, café, golosinas y refrescos naturales. El sueño de María es que su pequeño negocio se mantenga por que es por medio de este trabajo que ella sobrevive.
texts.en:
Maria Elena M. is 60 years old, and is married. Maria has 4 children and they all work independently. She owns a small grocery store; for over 9 years she has dedicated herself to this humble activity. She began this business by means of a friend who taught her how to get head economically, this helped Maria become a fighter; it’s also worth mentioning that even her age does not hinder her from having the spirit to serve her clients happily. This loan will be used as work capital to purchase basic grains, bread, coffee, sweets, and natural drinks. Maria’s dream is that her small business continues running because this work is how she survives.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Work capital.

loans.name: Friday

texts.en: Friday sells drinks and provisions. He is 42 years old and married with seven children. He hopes for the loan of N50,000 to purchase more drinks and provisions to sell. He is grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Santa Lucia Group

texts.en:
Santa Lucia is a group which formed in the city of Capiatá on January 27, 2009, thanks to its General Director, Mrs. Nilda C., who works at making and selling food. She contacted the advisor of a weekly meeting in the area in order to find out about the work done by committees of enterprising women. Once she joined the program, she was able to group 16 women, who are working together in their second cycle within the program. 

The average credit given per participant is 475,000 Gs, which goes to different activities such as the sale of: food, hardware, grocery store items, clothing, lingerie, ice cream, etc. 

All of them take part in their activities to earn money, and mutually help each other to reach their common goals within the group and with the Paraguayan Foundation. 

1. Nilda C. ..... Food sales 
2. Lilia M. ..... Food sales 
3. Myrian D. ..... Cosmetic sales 
4. Gloria V. ..... Small grocery store 
5. Mirian F. ..... Small grocery store 
6. Rosa Ortiz ..... Food sales 
7. María S. ..... Ice cream sales 
8. Claudelina V. ..... Fruit and vegetables sales 
9. Zoraida R. ..... Small grocery store 
10. Carolina A. ..... Hardware store

12. Ana S. ..... Lingerie sales 
13. María A. ..... Small grocery store 
14. Eliodora S. ..... Clothing sales 
15. Rita F. ..... Food sales 
16. Elizabeth V. ..... Clothing sales

loans.use: To purchase items for their various businesses

loans.name: Efosa

texts.en: Efosa has a farm where he plants cassava, corn and plantain. He is 46 years old and married with 9 children. He hopes for the loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more plantain suckers to grow. He says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more plantain suckers to grow

loans.name: Maria De Los Angeles

texts.es: María de los Ángeles T. tiene 40 años, es madre soltera. Tiene 3 hijos a su cargo. La actividad económica de María es la venta de refrescos y compra de cosméticos y. Hace más de 2 años que se dedica a este negocio. Sus inicios se dan  porque necesitaba sufragar los gastos de su familia, además ella labora como conserje en un centro de salud porque con lo poco que gana aquí no cubre los gastos suficientes para cubrir sus estudios,  y decide establecer en su vivienda la venta de ciertos refrescos como pozol, cebada, tiste por lo que este negocio le ayudo mucho.  Además María sigue luchando por estudiar y salir adelante. El destino del financiamiento es para capital de trabajo para la compra de maíz, pozol, cebada y además en la compra de cosméticos como cremas, perfumes entre otros. El sueño de María es permanecer con ambos negocios ya que y obtener los ingresos necesarios para mantener a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Maria de los Angeles T., 40, is a single mother. She has 3 children, all of whom she supports. She operates a business buying and selling cold drinks and cosmetics. She's operated the business for more than 2 years. She started it because she needed a way to defray her family's expenses. She also works as a cleaner at a health center but the little that she earns there isn't enough to cover [her? the children's?] schooling and she decided to set up the business at home selling cold drinks such as pozol [a local drink made from cacao and maize], cebada [a local drink made from barley] and tiste [a local drink made from cacao]. Maria continues struggling to study and get ahead. The loan will be used to buy maize, pozol and cebada, as well as cosemetics. Maria's dream is to keep both businesses so that she can have the income she needs to support her children.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase materials for farming.

loans.name: Uyimwen

texts.en: Uyimwen has a farm where she plants cassava and corn. She is 60 years old and married with 8 children. She hopes for a loan in the amount of N70,000 to purchase more cassava stems to plant. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cassava stems to plant.

loans.name: Jose Lenin

texts.es: José Lenin Vale R. tiene 55 años, es un hombre soltero. Tiene a su cargo 3 hijos y todos estudian. La actividad económica de José es la venta y elaboración de ataúdes. Hace más de 30 años que se dedica a este negocio. José inicio este negocio por cuenta propia ya que el asistía a una escuela taller y así fue que aprendió este oficio y decide establecer un lugar en su vivienda para ofrecer sus ataúdes. Sin embargo los problemas que José enfrentaba no lograron que siguiera luchando. El dinero que solicita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de pega, madera, clavos, pintura, tela entre otros productos de materia prima. El sueño de José es ampliar su negocio y generar mayor utilidad.
texts.en:
Jose Lenin Vale R., 55, is a single man. He supports 3 children, all in school. He operates a business making and selling coffins. He's worked at coffin-making for more than 30 years. He started the business on his own after attending a school-workshop where he learned the trade. He decided to set up a place in his house where he could sell his coffins. The problems that Jose faced never kept him from continuing to struggle [to get ahead?]. The money that he wants to borrow is for working capital to buy wood, nails, paint and other basic materials. Jose's greatest hopes are to expand his business and generate more income.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en:
Mrs. Cynthia is 25 years old and lives with Mr. Cándido, with whom she has two young children, and one more on the way. She lives in a neighborhood very close to the center of the city of Ita. She has had her own house for just a little time, while before, she was living with her mother.

Thanks to her work as a tobacco saleswoman, she was able to construct a two-level house with one bathroom. She inherited her business from her mother. She makes the tobacco at home, and then sells it in the Municipal Market in the mornings. The loan applied for is to buy more bundles of raw materials, due to her large number of orders.

loans.use: To buy more bundles of raw materials

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria is 54 years old and married with six children. She plants cassava and pineapple on her farm. She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase pineapple suckers to plant. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more pineapple suckers to plant

loans.name: Melkys Del Socorro

texts.es: La joven Melkys del Socorro L. tiene 22 años, es madre soltera. Doña Melkys tiene un hijo a su cargo y todavía no estudia. La actividad económica  es la venta de cosméticos de manera ambulante. Hace más de 3 años que se dedica a este negocio. Sus inicios son se dieron porque tenia que mantener a su familia, lo mas difícil para Melkys es dejar a su Mama mucho tiempo sola, por lo que ella necesita mucho cuidado. Pero esto no le impide a Melkys seguir con su negocio. Y así decide solicitar ayuda por medio de Fundación León 2000 para la compra de materia prima como cremas, perfumes, lápiz labial y delineadores entre otros. El sueño de Melkys es que su hermano logre finalizar sus estudios.
texts.en:
Young Melkys del Socorro L., 22, is a single mother. Dona Melkys has a son, not yet in school, who she supports. She works as a street vendor, selling cosmetics, work that she's been doing for more than 3 years. She started the business because she had to support her family. The thing that's most difficult for her is leaving her mother alone much of the time because her mother needs a lot of care. That doesn't stop Melkys from working, though. She's applying for a Fundacion Leon 2000 loan to buy products such as creams, perfumes, lipsticks, etc. for resell. Her greatest hope is that her brother succeeds in completing his studies.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella has a farm where she plants maize and pineapple. She is 44 years old and married with five children. She hopes for the loan of N70,000 to purchase more pineapple suckers to plant. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more pineapple suckers to plant

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase seeds, insecticides, fertilizers, chemical products, etc.

loans.name: Maria Bernarda

texts.es: María Bernarda R. Gracia tiene 73 años de edad. Es madre soltera. Y tiene 5 hijos a su cargo y todos estudian. La actividad económica es una pulpería. Hace más de 21 años que se dedica a este negocio. Doña María decidió iniciar este negocio por la necesidad de buscar el sustento diario para sus hijos por lo que ella, siempre ha sido una mujer muy responsable además fue madre y padre para sus hijos. Por lo que los financiamientos le han permitido comprar lo necesario para su negocio y comprar mayores cantidades de productos. El dinero que solicita es para capital de trabajo en la compra de granos básicos, golosinas, refrescos naturales. Su deseo es mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda.
texts.en:
Maria Bernarda R. Gracia, 73, is a single mother. She supports 5 children, all in school. She operates a small general store, a business that she's had for more than 21 years. Dona Maria decided to start the business because she needed to find a way to support her children. She's always been a very responsible woman and someone who has had to be both mother and father to her children. The loans have allowed her to buy what she needs for the business and wholesale supplies of the products she sells. The money that she wants to borrow will be used as working capital to buy basic grains, snacks and natural drinks. Her greatest hope is to make improvements to her house.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The purchase of an electric oven and merchandise such as sodas, beers, etc.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is 37 years old and married with five children. She plants cassava, maize and pineapple on her farm. She hopes for the loan of N70,000 to purchase cassava stems and pineapple suckers to plant. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pineapple suckers and cassava stems to plant

loans.name: Nicolás

texts.en:
Mr. Nicolás is a 43-year-old businessman married to Mrs. Mirta, who is 34 years old, and with whom he has four children: Ana who is 14; Liz who is 12; Rossana who is 11; and Richard who is 9. 

All of their children are continuing their studies thanks to the efforts of their parents who work daily to bring up the family, as they, themselves, did not have the opportunity to study.

Nicolás has a small grocery store, which he runs out of his home, and currently generates good earnings. He started this activity in 2004. At the beginning it was difficult because he needed capital to work, and with his children it was even harder. 

With much effort and with the help of his family, the business was able to continue ahead, and today it is a well-supported business.

loans.use: To purchase dairy products, meat, noodles, beer, sodas, deli meats, vegetables, etc.

loans.name: Ramiro Eleuterio

texts.es: El señor Ramiro Eleuterio T. C. tiene 60 años de edad, todos sus hijos son mayores de edad y cada uno tiene su familia por lo que ahora don Ramiro debe luchar por su propio sustento. El se dedica a la elaboración y reparación de zapatería desde hace 20 años, además vende productos que se utilizan en este oficio y esta es la principal fuente de ingreso de su hogar, es este el motivo que lo incita a realizarle mejoras a su pequeño negocio. Su mayor anhelo es mantener en funcionamiento su negocio y que Dios le de salud, en estos precisos momentos Ramiro esta necesitado de un financiamiento, que le permita comprar los materiales que le mantienen la actividad de su trabajo, necesita invertir en: cuero, cuerina, suelas, cordones, hormas, pega clavos moldes y otros materiales que son de suma importancia en este trabajo.
texts.en:
Sr. Ramiro Eleuterio T. C. is 60 years old. All of his children are grown and they each have their own families so Don Ramiro must struggle to make his way by himself. He has made a living making and repairing shoes for 20 years. He also sells products that are used by this market and that is the main source of his income which, in turn, is what motivated him to make improvements to the business. His greatest hopes are to keep the business running and, God willing, his health. Ramiro now needs a loan to buy the materials he needs to continue his business. He needs to buy: leather, cuerina [a synthetic leather], soles, laces, shoetrees, nails and other materials required for this kind of work.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase rice, sugar, drinks, and other general merchandise

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is 33 years old and married with four children. She sells bags of cocoa and she is also a farmer. She hopes for the loan of N70,000 to purchase more bags of cocoa to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of cocoa to sell

loans.name: Jairo Hilario

texts.es: Jairo Hilario C. M. tiene 45 años, es un hombre soltero. Tiene 5 hijos y todos estudian. La actividad económica es una pulpería. Hace más de 8 años que se dedica a este negocio. El inicio este negocio por su familia, desde muy pequeño por que le  gustaba este tipo de negocio y además relacionarse con sus vecinos, ya que es un hombre muy amistoso y alegre. Todos los financiamientos que ha solicitado son destinados para capital para la compra de golosinas, gaseosas, refrescos naturales y pan. Jairo tiene los sueños de seguir trabajando ya que es la única fuente de ingresos que tiene su familia.
texts.en:
Jairo Hilario C. M. is 45 years old. He is a single man, and he has five children who go to school. He has had a mini market for over eight years. He started the business for his family. Since he was very little he has liked this type of business. He also likes socializing with his neighbors; he is a friendly and happy man. All of the loans that he has asked for are for working capital to buy sweets, soft drinks, natural soft drinks, and bread. Jairo’s dream is to keep working since he is the only source of income that the family has.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience plants pineapples, peppers and plantain on her farm. She is 46 years old and married with two children. She hopes for the loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more pineapple suckers to plant. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more pineapple suckers to plant

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy E. has a pineapple and plantain farm. She is 53 years old and married with five children. She hopes for the loan of N70,000 to clear her farm and purchase more pineapple and plantain suckers to plant. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To clear her farm and purchase more pineapple and plantain suckers to plant

loans.name: Elizabeth Del Carmen

texts.es: Elizabeth del Carmen M. Gutiérrez tiene la edad de 37 años. Es una mujer casada. Tiene 4 hijos y todos estudian. La actividad económica es venta de ropa y de CD. Hace más de 9 años que se dedica a este negocio. Sus propósitos con su negocio son ampliar su inventario para que la demanda solicitada por sus clientes sea satisfactoria. Con los financiamientos ha logrado crecer con su negocio. Es por eso que los financiamientos son destinados para capital de trabajo en la compra de mercadería como ropa para damas, ropa para niños y ropa interior. El deseo de Elizabeth es adquirir un puesto en el mercado donde ofrecerá a sus productos a una variada clientela.
texts.en:
Elizabeth del Carmen M. Gutiérrez is 37 and married. She has four children who go to school. She sells clothes and CDs. She has been doing this for more than nine years. Her plan for the business is to increase her inventory so that her supply can meet demand, and her customers will be satisfied. With loans she has been able to expand her business. That is why the loans are for working capital to buy merchandise like women’s clothes, children’s clothes, and underwear. Elizabeth’s wish is to get a place in the market where she can sell her products to various customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Nelly

texts.es:
Primer préstamo: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=89342&_tpos=1&_tpg=1
Nelly es socia del bancomunal Maria de la Paz.
Trabajaba en comedores populares, en vaso de leche, cocinando pero era muy cansado, quiso cambiar de actividad, se dedica a la Venta de productos de belleza por catalogo, ella trabaja con tres líneas. 
En Finca aprendió a ser perseverante, para lograr lo que quiere.
Necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles para la compra de productos por catalogo que comprara por el día del padre.
El sueño que tiene es  terminar de construir su casa.
texts.en:
First loan: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=89342&_tpos=... Nelly is a member of the Maria de la Paz Community Bank. She used to work in popular restaurants and for Vaso de Leche (Glass of Milk), a program that provides food to vulnerable citizens in Peru. She cooked, but she was very tired. She wanted to change jobs. She now sells beauty products by catalog. She works with three lines. In Finca she learned to persevere in order to achieve what she wants. She needs a loan for 1,000 PEN to buy catalog products that will be sold for Father’s Day. Her dream is to finish construction on her house.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy catalog products that will be sold for Father’s Day

loans.name: Rosa Maria

texts.es:
Primer préstamo: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=89343&_tpos=7&_tpg=1
Rosa Maria es socia del bancomunal Maria de la Paz
Se dedica   reparto  diario menú, solo trabaja por las mañanas, su clientela ha aumentado, también por las tardes se dedica al  bordando en lentejuelas y al tejido a crochet por las tardes, que le esta generando una entrada mas.
